DIV1.P: Subtilty and Cruelty: OR A TRUE RELATION OF Sr Sackvile Crow HIS Designe of seizing and possessing himselfe of all the Estate of the English in TURKY.
WITH The Progresse he made, and the Meanes he used in the execution thereof.
Manifested by sundry Warrants, Instructions, and Letters under his owne hand and Seale, and by other evidence.

DIV1.HEAD: To the READER.
DIV1.P: THe mutuall complaints of the Turky Company and Sr Sackvile Crow late Embassador in Turky, being eminently publique; and many scandals being cast upon the Merchants, and upon the present Embassador, by private whispers of Sr Sackvile and his Agents: It is become even necessary to expose the following papers to publique view; being the copies of Sr Sac. Crowes Warrants, Instructions and Letters to his Agents, and of some of their Returnes: together with the Factors letters unto the Company here; giving an account of his attempts against them.

And whosoever shall esteeme it worth his time to be truly informed of the matters in difference, as they depended before the late, and this present Parliament; may collect from these Papers, the true state of the controversie: The most materiall of which are confes∣sed by Sr Sackvile Crow before a Committee of Parlia∣ment, to have passed under his own hand and Seale; and the others also will be as easily proved.

But be pleased first to understand the relation be∣tween the Levant (or Turky) Company and Sr Sackvile Crow. He was first employed in the yeare 1638. as Embassador or Agent to Constantinople: and although he was dignified (as was usual) with the title of the Kings Embassador or Resident, and his Commission; yet it was not an Embassy upon matters of State, there being only Capitulations and peace for freedom of Trade between the Turkes and the English; and Sr Sackvile Crow, under that honorable name, was the Levant Com∣panies Agent or publique Minister, upon severall agree∣ments and covenants mutually passed between them:
and as Their Agent only, the Company paid for the transportation and provision of himselfe, his Lady, and all his retinue: and also gave him Sixe hundred pounds as advance, for the furniture and ornament of his house at Constantinople: and covenanted to allow him a year∣ly Salary of neere Two thousand five hundred pounds sterling; which was paid him quarterly beforehand. And He covenanted to take care of the publique good of the Companies trade, and impartially to see it ordered by the rules and orders made by them: and to assist their Treasurer to cause the costs and charges of any Avania, (or Turkish charge upon fictitious pretences) that should happen upon a Nationall cause, to be borne by all the Company of Tradrs there, in indifferent proportions, as their Treasurer and the English nation there should thinke fit: and that he should not exact any Levy of moneys, or forcibly take the goods or moneys of any of the Traders there, upon any pretence what∣soever without the Companies order under Seale. This was the summe and substance of the trust reposed by the Company in Sr Sackvile Crow, (with some other things less materiall) to which he was obliged by Articles under his hand and seale.

Now the most gross, palpable and infamous breach of this publique trust, to the high dishonour of the En∣glish nation in the eyes of Turkes and Infidels, and to the utmost hazard of the loss and ruine of a very im∣portant part of the English Trade, and of the lives and fortunes of many of the English Nation, This is the subject matter of the Levant Companies complaint against Sr Sackvile Crow: and the following Papers speak enough to be sufficient proof on their behalfe: from these every judicious eye may collect cleere evidence, that Sr Sackvile Crow did not only cast aside that care of the publique good of the Companies trade, and observing their
rules and orders, unto which he was obliged by Covenant; But also that he assumed and usurped to himselfe an absolute arbitrary power over all the Companies Estates in Turky, and their Factors Persons; and to be their absolute and supreme Judge even in his own case; and that he demeaned himselfe, as if he had been absol∣ved from all his Covenants; pursuing by all undue meanes of force and fraud his private interest, to the ruine of the Trade. And to make these Papers speake in method and order, be pleased (good Reader) to ob∣serve from them,
1. Sr Sackvile Crowes Secret designe;See page 15. 19 32. 47. 53. 55. as himselfe calls it, to his own Servants.
2. The Disguises he cunningly deviseth to cover the frighting Deformity of it, at least untill he had compas∣sed it.
3. The Meanes directed and ordered by him, for the effecting his designe.
4. The proceedings he made towards the Execution of his designe, before the English in Turky could avoid his oppression.

I. First, the Warrants, Instructions and Letters given under Sr Sackviles hand and seale, to his servants John Hetherington and Lorenzo Zuma discover with open face, that he designed to make himselfe Master of all the English Estates in Turky. The very words of his se∣cond Warrant are these,See Page 8. We hereby inorder sequestra∣tion of all moneys, Merchandizes and other goods and faculties whatsoever within the dminions of the Grand Signor where∣ever belonging to the members of the said Company in theThere was a Shedule of 64 names which had all the con∣siderable estates there. vid. fol. Schedule annexed; Requiring you to boad and enter all Ships and Vessels, and to breake open and enter into all and every the Houses, Ware-houses and Compting-houses of all and every the said parties; and to take, carry away, and put into safe
custody, all such moneys, Merchandize, goods and other facul∣ties of what nature soever, that you shall discover, find out and get into your power &c. And in his letter to Hethering∣ton, he commands himPage 33. to hinder Jorden and all other Masters of ships from lading, till he was Master of what he aymed at. And in another letter to Hetherington, he tells him thus;Page 49. You have order for rendring into your possession all goods aboard the Ships, belonging to any of our Nation; for if it be for any English, I care not for whom, or if by any English laden, I care not by whom, sequester it.

And his intentions to graspe at no lesse then all, may appeare, not only by the21. 49. 51. 55. private carriage of his designe, enjoyning his Agents15. that no creature should know any part thereof; Noe19. not the French Druggerman em∣ployed by him in discovering the Merchants Estates: But by his express Instructions to them,16. 42. 47. 48. 54. to possesse themselves of what they could, without limitation: andPage 55. to exspect his further orders for the time of their seizing or plundering all there, that He might fall on to doe the same (which he called His worke) at Constantinople at the same time. And in ano∣ther letter to Lorenzo and Hetherington, he tells themPage 44. He is advised of an English Ship arrived about Smyrna, which by advice from within rides without, and resolves for Scanderone, and to discharge and relade there; But he hoped to get a command for the Chiaus to secure that other Corner also. And the same letters also give cleere evidence that his further designe was, to transport himselfe and the English estates he could swallow, out of Turky into some other forraine Nati∣on; As in another letter to his complices,Page 33. 85. Upon your advice, I shall make use of some one of these Ships here, to transport my Wife and family, and provide for the rest in time.

And he31. 32. severall times orders his Agents to agree with shipping at high rates, to transport the goods he
had plundered from the English. And the Reader may observe in severall passages22. 24. 83. how highly Sr Sack∣vile was inraged at the stealing any English goods aboard, or the departure of any ship: He esteeming it all to be lost out of his purse; having swallowed in his hopes the whole English estate in that Empire. And he was so confident in the face of the Sun to avow the making himselfe a fortune upon the Companies estates there (for that was his sole, and utmost end what ever may now be suggested)6. 7. 8. 74. 80. 81. That he demanded of the Fa∣ctors at once, Twenty five thousand pounds Sterling, for his Estate which he said was sequestred in England; and neere Ten thousand pounds Sterling for his hopes of future profits by his Embassy for seven years: and tells them that untill they had paid it him, neither their Persons nor Estates should be free; for he had vowed to God at the last Sacrament to sacrifice his Estate, Himselfe, Wife and Children, for the execution of this his absolute intent.

II. Secondly, these following Papers will shew the Disguises which Sr Sackvile Crow invented and practi∣sed, for the more plausible carrying on this his grand and black Designe. First, he imposed a Leviation or taxe upon the English Estates, of a Hundred and ten thousand Dollars; under colour of a necessity for so much to satisfy the Companies debts: Requiring the same to be paid in ready money, when he told his Agents15. 16. he knew it to be impossible; whom yet he instructed to take no security,16. no not all the Nation for one mans taxe: Nei∣ther would he allow any time, when the Factors would submit to his Leviation, if they might have time to raise the money: But in pursuance of his secret Designe, he gives out Warrants and Instructions to Enter Warehouses and Comptinghouses, and seize upon all Goods, Money and Mer∣chandizes; that thereby he might not only have occa∣sion
to begin to rifle the English Estates, but to Discover them; and this with less odium and scandall from the Turkes and Iewes, and with more assistance from the Turkish officers, then would have bin, if his secret De∣signe had been fallen upon bare-faced. Yet to make it beyond dispute, that This was only intended in order to the designe of swallowing up all; The Reader may please to observe that this Leviation was and is by Sr Sackvile himselfe acknowledged to be a15. 16. 16. 18. 19. 47. 48. Colour: His Agents being ordered38. to make that the ground∣worke of all their other worke; and49. not to discover his owne pretences till the last. As also that some of the Factors, hoping to prevent his further oppression, made tender of their part of the Leviation in money to Sr Sackvile Crow himselfe; and he refused it, and gave order to his Agents at Smyrna,29. to arrest the person and goods of Mr. Daniell Edwards, that offered it, notwithstan∣ding his tender of his money; and said he longed to have him in his power. And Mr. Nathaniel Brandon, another of the Factors, offering likewise his part, Sr Sackvile refu∣sed it, unless he would discover where all his Estate re∣mained; which Mr Brandon denying, Sr Sackvile sends for his Broker, commanding a discovery from him, as also from Mr James Mudiford: But they still refusing, Sr Sackvile vowed that if it were between Heaven and Earth he would find it out: & thereupon, on Sr Sackviles command, Mr Brandon was clapt in Chaines. Nay30. 34. the full of the Leviation would not be accepted:40. 48. Nor being paid, might the Factors be afterwards at liberty to lade their goods; But29. 30. still his instruments are directed to seize. And this first disguise of a Leviation, carried Two more in his bowels; The one was, a seizure of more goods for charges, when they had enough double and treble for the Leviation; and those he set at 36000
Dollars: The other was to appraise the goods his A∣gents should Seize, at halfe values; That when his new pretences for his secret Designe should come, he might not want colour for swallowing up the whole.

The next maske of his designe was a meere fained pretencePage 7 that the Parliament had sequestred his Estate in England, by the companies procurement; and therefore He would repaire himselfe out of theirs in Turky: and then he values his Estate at 297000 Dol∣lars (neere 80000 pound sterling) whereas it is belei∣ved that he had not a visible Estate to 3000 pound Value.

An other pretence was,6. 7 29. a claime of 174000 Dol∣lars for Consulage due to him; although he had con∣tracted under hand and Seale with the Company to assist in collecting that money for Them, to be paid to Their Treasurer; That being the usuall Receipt out of which the Com∣pany defray the extraordinary Charge of the Embassa∣dor and other Ministers abroad. But as he instructed his servants about the seizing some of the Factors per∣sons,50. 51. to Make a pretence, if they could not find one, for (he said) it was all one to him, so the worke were done; So he practiseth himselfe to forge and invent pretences to devoure the Companies Estates; that his rapine and violence might not be seene unmasked, least they should have lost the opportunity to act it.
III. Thirdly, Let the Reader observe from these papers what unhappy Meanes, suitable to his Ends, he found out for compassing his designe.

1. By false insinuations to the Vizier, he procures countenance from him for an Embargo: And there∣upon1. 4. 11. 23. 26. 39. 41. 45. he arrests all the ships of the English at Smirna and Constantinople; and prohibites also the Lading of any goods; and commands the persons of any that should presume to lade,
to be arrested; and those that could not be apprehended, to be proclaimed26. 35. 69. Rebells: and so he afterwardes styled most of the English Nation there. And he further com∣mands44. 45. 46. Accounts to be given to his Agents by the Masters of the ships, of all the goods on board; and they to enter into all Ships, Warehouses or Counting houses; and to take into their power all Bookes of Accompts, Bills of Debt, Acquittan∣ces, Letters, or other writings or evidence whatsoever belon∣ging to any English whatsoever; and the same to keepe and and make use of in evidence. Thus underPage 31. 33. 35. a feyned Co∣lour of command from that State, he practised to im∣mure the whole English Estate, that none might escape his fingers.

2. He ordered Rewards and promises to be made and given to Informers (without reserving his Agents within any bounds) that they might discover the mo∣neys, goods and debts of the Company. AndPage 16. He orders his servants to employ some Jew or Armenian Brokers (under pretence of Bargains) to discover the English Estates: And his AgentsPage 58. make him returne to these Instructions, That they had employed the most cunning Rogues in all the Countrey, to see if they could discover any other part of the Nations Estate either hid or lying out.

3. He orderedPage 10. 18. 20. 32. 35. 36. 41. 50. the Bribing of the Cady, the Neipe, the Chiaus, the Customer, and all the Turkish officers and in∣ferior ministers, to gaine their assistance in his designe: and herein he gives his AgentsPage 21. Latitude without limit; and tells them againe and againePage 10. 18. 19. 20. 41. That they must spare no Cost; assuring them they may charge 10000 Dollars upon him by bills for that use, and commands themPage 52. 54. to pawne the goods they seaze, for the same end; That they might buy the Turkish Ministers to execute his cruelty upon the Factors, and helpe to possess him of the companies Estate. And to make his Agents most impudent and
fearless in what they did, he gives them assurance in a boasting mannerPage 38. That the Merchants should never have right against them, so long as they themselves had any thing to bribe the contrary: and he bad themPage 53. Value themselves and their service at what rate they pleased, and they should be recompensed.

4. He ordered his Servants to ingratiate themselves with all the Turkes; who were apt to mutiny by see∣ing the horrid rapine and injustice executed upon the traders with whom they dealt: and therefore he com∣manded them to spare no charge in presents,Page 18. 40. 63. to make the very Townsmen of their party; and to perswade them that all that was done, was intended for the better regulation and advance of Trade; which he said was only in his power to increase and regulate.

5. And yet to Secure himselfe of the whole English Estate more certainly, he tooke care to prevent the interposition of the justice of the very Infidells, which he feared might protect the Merchants from his oppres∣sion: Therefore he informed the Vizier,Page 26. that divers English ships were joyned with the Venetian Fleet, the Turkes Enemy, and attended to give Battle to the Grand Signiors Fleete: and alsoPage 82. that some ships had been Laden by the Merchants with Powder and prohibited goods, for the Enemies supplies: AndPage 69. counsells his Servants at Smirna to procure from the Turkish Ministers there, most dangerous and false Cer∣tificates, That the Factors perswaded the people of the place to mutinie: By this meanes exposing the Factors per∣sons at least to Slavery in the Gallies, if not death by Torments, and the Companies Estates to a certaine confiscation; if the Vizier himselfe had not discerned his falseness and Avanious designes against his own Nation. And though his allegations had not full credit;
yet, by them he obstructed, at least for a time, the only meanes of releife which the factors could expect; hoping in the interim to make sure of most of their Estate.

Thus He that was employed and trusted cheifely (as occasion should happen) to mediate with the Grand Signor and his Ministers that the Capitulations be∣tween him and the English might be kept,See Capitula∣tions. At. 16. as sacred and inviolate; and that noe English Causes between themselves might be under the jurisdiction of the Tur∣kish Ministers (the Grand Signor having granted, for our Nations security, that his Officers should not inter∣meddle therein) Even He that was thus trusted, having designed to make his private fortunes out of the Com∣panies Estates; endeavoured to his utmost to bring all the Nation there, under the Tyranny of the Turkish Ministers; conjuring his Servants to make noe ScruplePge 50. to use the Turkish ayde against the Merchants persons and Estates, whatever came of it.
IV. Fourthly, These papers will give you an account what progresse Sr Sackvile Crow made in the Execution of his intended rapine.

1. His Orders for arresting the Ships in port, tooke such unhappy effect, by his subtilty in gaining Impe∣riall Commands upon false suggestions,P. 78. that some ships were stayed in port neare 7 moneths; to an insuppor∣table damage of the Merchants.
2. He actually. forced the payment of 110000 Dollars, under colour of a Leviation: and alsoPage 80 Bonds for 25000 Dollars, under colour of maintenance for himselfe and his family.

3. His Servants prevailed so effectually with the Turkish officers, That * they seized and imprisoned, first the Consul and most principall of the Factors at
Smirna; and afterwards most of the rest: and with Bar∣barous crueltyPage 91. haled the Consul and Sixe of the cheife of that factory to a darke and close Dungeon, with the doores and windowes nailed upon them, in the extreame heate of Summer: Where they had in probability perished, if the mercy of the Turkes had not been prevailed upon with a bribe of 100 Dollars, to exceed the mercy of Sr Sackviles Servants, and to open a window for light and ayre. And at the same time they forced away from the Consul there the Imperiall Capitulations, which were the only security of the English against Death or Slavery by the Turkes. And within a few daies they hurried their Prisoners with Turkish guards 350 miles overland to Constantinople, to imprison them in Sr Sackvile Crowes owne House: Many of their fellow Factors being soone after brought in like manner to partake of the same bondage. And what he acted by his cruel Agents at Smirna, He him∣selfe undertooke to execute upon the Factory at Con∣stantinople; where taking the opportunity of a Gene∣rall Court or meeting of the Nation; He caused the Gates to be shut, and by surprise tooke them all his Prisoners; and set strong guards upon them, to prevent all accesse to them, and their sending the least paper abroad; some of them also being clapt in Chaines.

4. He caused the Counting houses, Warehouses and Chambers of the English at Constantinople, to be sei∣zed and sealed up. And his servants Hetherington and Zuma did the same to the whole English Nation at Smirna; and proceeded also to breake open and ran∣sake all their Chambers, Trunkes and Counting houses; and to plunder and carry away unto Turkish Canes, all money, goods, faculties and effects whatsoever they could find, either at home or abroad: Exposing their
Servants and Families to the mercy of the Infidells for their subsistence.

P. 83.5. He breathed forth most severe threats and me∣naces by his Agents, against the Servants and families of the Factors, to extort from them discovery and con∣fession of their Masters Estates and debts, and for deli∣very of their Bookes; intending to devoure the whole: and the dread of the Turkish Souldiers and Officers (whose tiranny was so higly menaced) so affrighted the Factors Servants, that they fled to ships for refuge; leaving the plundered Houses to the open world.

Thus the Reader will find Sr Sackvile Crowes Cruelty and vigor in Executing, to be no less, then his subtilty and policy in Contriving his designe of rapine upon the Companies Estates: and if the outcries and clamors of the Jewes and Turkes against such horrid oppres∣sions and destructive courses to all future Trade,P. 82. 93. to∣gether with some Presents made to the Vizier by some few of the factors that fortunately escaped imprison∣ment, had not caused the Turkish justice to interpose, and redeeme the Merchants Estates, and the Factors persons from his cruell and covetous hands, his designe had certainly been fully successefull.

Now let the Reader judge whether the Company were not obliged for their owne preservation, upon ad∣vice of these horrid attempts of Sr Sackvile Crow, to seeke some present redress. And this they did by hum∣ble addresses to the late Parliament, who were pleased to orderP. 95. his Revocation; and by ordinance of Par∣liamentP. 97. to authorise Sr Thomas Bendishe to be Em∣bassador in Sr Sackvile Crowes stead. Yet when Sr Tho∣mas Bendishe arrived) Sr Sackvile contemnes the autho∣rity whereby he was sent; and pretends him to be no other then an Impostor, who had counterfeited Com∣missions
for an Embassy; although his authority (being both from the King and the Parliament) was as great as ever any Embassador carried into Turky: and he secretly insinuated to the Vizier, that the English Nation there were most of them Rebells; and Sr Thomas Bendyshe intended to be their Head: Suggest∣ing also that he had Letters from the King to the Grand Signor for his owne continuance in the Embassy; hoping to have hindered the reception of Sr Thomas Bendyshe. But when the falsehood of his pretences ap∣peared to the Vizier, He caused his owne officers to send him on board a Turkish Vessell to Smirna, to be from thence shipped for England, to be dealt with ac∣cording to his demerits. And upon his arrivall here in April 1648,Page 99. the Parliament committed him Pri∣soner to the Tower of London in order to his Tryall; and referred the Companies Complaints to be exami∣ned by the Committie for the Navy: and severall witnesses in the case were by them examined; although the Report was not made, through the cunning arti∣fices of S• Sackvile Crow to delay the full hearing of the Cause. But it is humbly submitted to every ingenuous Reader, whether there was not cause sufficient to send home Sr Sackvile Crow: and whether S Thomas Bendishe was not obliged in faithfulnsse to his trust, to proceed as he did, in order to the performing his owne Embas∣sy: And whether the hand of Justice might not have fallen heavy upon Sr Sackvile Crow, if there had been that vigorous prosecution which the blacknesse of his designes against the Company might have provoked them unto. Yet if Sr Sackvile had not by private in∣formations, and by pamplets (in a very secret and un∣ingenuous way dispersed) lately endeavoured to blast the Companies and the Embassadors reputation; and
also to have insinuated most false complaints of great injuries done to him by the Company; and if he had not commenced vexatious Suites at Law against them, upon hopes of dvantage by the patience and forbea∣rance they have shewed towards him: These his crimes had not been made thus publique; being done without thought of Malice or prejudice to his person; and not without greife and shame That one who enjoyed so faire an Income from the Company, and underwent but an easy Expence, and therefore could not but be master of a very ample Estate; should thus betray them who intrusted and maintained him; and so wilfully purchase ruine to himselfe, with the expence of his owne fortunes, and above one hundred thousand Pounds loss to the Company.

DIV2.HEAD: Sir Sackvile Crow his Order, dated in Pera of Constanti∣nople the 26th of January, 1645. Directed to all Cap∣tains, Commanders of Ships, &c. Prohibiting the lading of any Goods or Estate on their Ships.
DIV2.P:
WHereas by the unhappy failings of som of our Nations here, and at Smyrna, and through the many late changes of this State's Officers, and their extravagant exa∣ctions on us in those difficulties; and by sundry other avanious wayes▪ our nation is brought into a great Debt; For which, Wee, or those, and that Estate which shall remain on the place, who, and whatever in case of exigent, and force for payment, when ever that shall happen, must (if not otherwise provided for) in all probability, and according to the rude Customes of this State in like case, look to bee made liable unto. There beeing at present a full and competent E∣state of the Levant Companies arrived here and at Smyrna, which as well by the obligations of their Charter, as by the Laws of England, the said Companies own Institutions and Customes, in cases of like nature, ought as well to bear the said extraor∣dinary as ordinary Charges, and so pay those Debts which ei∣ther are, or shall bee adjudged and declared to belong unto them. Wee having taken pains in drawing the said Accomts to a head, and for the discovery of the truth thereof; and (after a Certi∣ficate being directed theron) for the more formall satisfaction onely of the said Company) being advertised that som of those who with us have had the view and been present at the exami∣nation of the said Accompts, whom it concerns on the Compa∣nies behalf to make such certificate, on our Order; for some pri∣vate respects, make scruple to certifie the said Debts, as they appeared before us and them: And hearing also that the Gene∣rall
Ships here in Port, and that at Smyrna, prepare, and make haste to bee gon; In Providence, as well for our own safety in the Premisses, as for that due regard wee owe to his Majesties Honor, and the publick interest for the future; Wee finde it requisite, and hereby order and require, that untill the said Debts shall bee fully declared, and their payment settled by Leviation, and the same paid or undertaken, in, and by som such fitting and secure way, or wayes as in such case is requisite, and by us shall bee determined and so declared; That none of the Factors of this scale, or that of Smyrna, by themselves, or others whoever, after publicaion hereof here and there respectively, lade on Board either of the Generall Ships, or other ships whatever, any Goods, faculty, or estate whatever, for themselves or other whoever: And that the Captains and Commanders of the said Shipps, in the mean time, and until Our farther Order in this behalfe, not onely forbear to take in, and lade aboard ei∣ther of their ships any such Goods or faculties for any of His Majesties Subjects, or other strangers whoever; but also that they abide and depart not, either this Port, or that of Smyrna respectively, untill our farther Order and License in that be∣half: whereof not onely the Merchants, Factors, Masters, and Commanders afore mentioned, but ourIntrepreters Druggermen, and other Under ministers here or there, are to take notice, and ob∣serv accordingly; as they, and every of them concerned herein, will answer the contrary at his or their peril.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Dated in Pera of Constantinople, this 26 of January, 1645.
CLOSER.SALUTE: To all Captains, Commanders of Ships, Merchants, Factors, Druggermen, and all other his Majesties Subjects and Ministers whoever in the Ports of Constantinople and Smyrna.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow

DIV2.HEAD: Sir Sakcvile Crowe's First Warrant, directed to John Hethering∣ton and Lorenzo Zuma, going for Smyrna; to apprehend and to send to Constantinople the Consul and factors not paying the Le∣viation, and to seize upon their Estate; and to probibite their tra∣ding. Dated 27. Apr. 1646.
DIV2.P:
VVhereas by vote of Court here, agreeable to the An∣cient and ever accustomed Rules of the Levant Compa∣nie in cases of like nature, and our orders thereon, a Leviation was agreed on for the payment of the said Companies debts, and that to bee had, made, or raysed on all goods and Merchan∣dize inward laden on the three General Ships, Hercules, Samp∣son, and Symrna Merchants, lately arrived at Smyrna or this Port, by an equal Avarage according to a Schedule hereunto annexed; which Schedule together with our order thereon of the 28th February last, beeing formerly sent to the Factory of Smyrna, and there (as by the said Factors general Letter to us directed, with the Consuls, and Coppies of Courts held by the said Consul there for that occasion, appears) beeing denied to bee complyed withall; and the said Factors persisting in their obstinacie, and still refusing to obey our said Orders, and to pay their parts of the said Leviation according thereunto and Schedule aforementioned? These are to will and require you John Hetherington and you Lorenzo Zvma to repair to Smyrna, and thereby virtue of the imperial Commands given into your hands to that end, by means of the Caddie, Viziers Baluck Bas∣sheê or Chouz sent to attend this service, or one of them, for the better example to the other, to apprehend and send to this Port, to bee delivered into our hands and custody, the Consul with six or eight of the chief of that Factory, and most refractorie, viz. John Lancelot Consul, Dixwell Brent Treasurer, Daniel Ed∣wards, Samuel Barnardiston, George Hanger, James Moyer, John Ball, John Englesby, and Henry Davy Factors; and in the mean time to seal up their Houses Ware-houses and Counting-houses with all and every of their goods Merchandize and facul∣ties whatever therein, untill farther order from us in that behalf; And for the rest (not paying the said Leviation and their re∣spective parts therein or giving that caution for the same in such
manner at by your instructions is directed) you are to seal up his and their and every of his or their Ware-houses and Coun∣ting-houses, and to seize and take into your Power, Custody, and Possession all his and their and every of their Goods Mer∣chandize and faculties whatever; untill hee or they refusing comply with our said Order for Leviation in manner aforesaid, viz, either by paying their parts or giving caution for the same to bee payed in such manner as by your instructions is directed; and in the mean time to prohibite them and every of them, Commerce or Trade by the way of buying, selling, Bartering or Trucking of any Commoditie whatever; and during that time not to suffer them or any of them so refusing, and delaying, to send on board any English Ship or Vessel Riding in the Port of Smyrna, nor any such Ship or Vessel, there to take on board or receiv any Goods Merchandize or faculties whatever, be∣longing to them or any of them; for which this is to bee your Warrant.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Dated in Pera of Constantinople. this 27th April 1646,
CLOSER.SALUTE: To our very loving friends and Servants: John Hethering∣ton and Lorenzo Zuma.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.HEAD: Sir Sackvile Crow his Second Warrant, dated in Pera of Constan∣tinople, the 30 of Aprill, 1646. directed to John Hetherington, Lorenzo Zuma; Enordering (upon fals pretences) the sequestra∣tion of the Merchants Estates at Smyrna, according to a Schedule.
DIV2.P:
WHereas the Levant Company, somtime before our com∣ming to this place, by a Court of their Assistants, there∣unto specially authorized, treated with us touching a yeerly allowance for our care and paines during our residence here as his Majesties Ambassador; to bee had and taken in such particu∣lars
as might have relation to their trade and occasions: And for a conclusion of such treaty as aforesaid, did offer unto us the election of any one of their agreements, formerly made with a∣ny of our Predecessors in like occasion. And for a further mani∣festation of their sincerity in their said offer, upon our accord thereunto, did at the Court aforesaid, in publick give into our Hands and possession the Copies of five of their agreements, made with our said Predecessors, with power to Choose which of them wee should best like of, to bee a rule and pattern for an absolute conclusion and condition to bee drawn up between us and them; thereon also promising that they would make, grant, and confirm the like unto us. And whereas wee thereon, and to the purposes and ends afore mentioned, chose and fixed upon that agreement, which the said Company had made with Sir Thomas Glover, formerly Ambassador, Resident for the Crown of England, with this state: and his Majestie by his favour did assure the same unto us, gratiously promising to make his em∣ployment of us here, as good and beneficial in all the alowances and perquisites thereof, as it had been to any of our Predeces∣sors whoever, and wee expected no less. The said Company, finding themselvs mistaken in their offer (as they pretended) first retired from the same, denying their said agreement (though sufficiently prooved before his Majestie) and then by force of presents and mony given under hand to the Officers of that time, so prevailed against us, that wee could not onely not ob∣tain that Right, which since hath appeared unto us, and (as well by their own agreement, as by his Majesties judgment then, Custome, and their former contracts) was due unto us; but were forced after to other agreements with the said Company, by which (over and above all such Rights, Privileges, and Per∣quisits, as then were and should bee granted unto us by his Ma∣jesties Capitulations, and besides all other gratifications and al∣lowances accustomed to bee given to his Majesties Ambassador, (which in houshold provisions, only the said Company, assured us were to the vallue of 800 l. per annum, sterling, at least) and over and above such Plate, and Houshold Stuff as they assured us, wee should finde of theirs here, and hold to our use during our residence, (of which wee found not the vallue of and Asper)
the said Company did covenant with us, (for and in respect of our paines and care only therein agreed to bee taken by us, in their affaires and occasions as aforesaid, for and during all our time as his Majesties Ambassador with this State,) they would pay or caus to bee paid unto us the sum of five thousandviij. Sterling. Chic∣keenes, per an., to be paid by equal proportions quarterly before∣hand; by their failing wherein (besides our other engagements for them to a very good vallue) twenty and five thousand Dollars or there abouts rests at this day due and unpaid unto us: And whereas also after the agreements aforesaid, upon several argu∣ments held before his Majestie, concerning the rights of that Consulage which amongst other things is granted by the Grand Signor, and payable by his Capitulations to his Majesties Am∣bassador Resident at this imperial Port from strangers, (to which the said Company could shew no likely or probable title) The said Company were adjudged to relinquish their pretences to the said Consulage; and a grant thereof under his Majesties Royal Hand and signet, was thereon made and given to us, for our better support during the time of our residence here. The said Company (upon conditions between them and us agreed) did also promise to give us content therefore; with intent ne∣vertheless thereby to get advantage of our credulity and ab∣sence, and to draw us out of suspect of their evil intentions to∣wards us, which hath since, (as well by their several interrupti∣ons and hinderances here in the Collection thereof, as their practises, and endeavours at Council Table before his Majestie, and by their other appeals to the Courts of Parlament, where in these times of distractions, they presumed of som better ad∣vantage) hath appeared unto us; Whereby, and by suggesting several untruths against us, and by other false wayes they have endeavoured not only to deprive us of the strangers Consulage, and benefit thereof; but under that colour also and these their pretences, to keep themselvs from paying, as us from taking such other Consulage, as was, and is as much our right, and due unto us from themselvs, by the said Capitulations and the Grand Signor's grant thereon, for all their own goods Traded in; And now of late, but suspecting our just intentions of ma∣king a claim thereto, (for untill this present day wee never made
any demand therefore, or publick pretence therein) to prevent what they suppose wee might justiy do in our own right, (for wee take God to Witness wee know no other caus) under like unjust and scandalous pretences, wee are certified that they not only go about to get us remooved from our employment here, but upon fals suggestions, loos and bare suspitions onely, have gotten Order for the seizure of all our Lands and other Estates in En∣gland into their power; as som of their own Servants and Fa∣ctors here have the confidence to report and affirm; and as wee are assured from thence, without hearing of us; nay, so much as intimation to us of the grounds thereof, or such matters and things as they pretend at least to have against us, whereby wee might answer for our selvs; and so, whil'st wee are labouring (as for these many years wee have don, with all fidelity for them and their publique Interest, (whereof, as wee have proof sufficient in our actions, so wee have him that is Judg of the World for witness to our Conscience) they are contriving the ruine of us and our Posterity; which manner of proceeding so unjust, horrid, and odious before God and Man (as in all reason wee ought) taking to heart and our serious consideration, and as well that violence which is offered to the Lawes, and his Ma∣jesties Honor and Interest therein, as our self and our family) not pretending to extend that authority which his Majestie hath put into our hands to unlawful ends, but only to make a just use of it for the right & lawful defens of our selvs & it in the several occasions aforementioned; finding by acompt under the hands of the Treasurer of the said Company here, that for such goods as they have brought in and carried out from the Port of Constantinople, there is due unto us according to the Capitu∣lations, and the Grand Signors grants therein, to the value of Dollars Ryals of 2/8, seventy four thousand; and that for the like in Smyrna there is due Dollars Ryals of 8/8, one hundred thousand in circa; and rating that Estate in Land which they have gotten into their power as aforesaid, but at the value wee were offered for it, viz. at ninety seven thousand and five hundred Dollars; in all, two hundred seaventy one thousand and five hundred Dollars. Besides, (for ought wee know to the contrary) they may els have prevailed themselvs upon of
ours; And as due to us by privy Seal to the value of one hun∣dred thousand Dollars; and Leases under the great Seal to near as great a value more. Wee hereby inorder sequestration of all Monies, Merchandizes, and other Goods and Faculties what∣ever, within the Dominions of the Grand Signor wherever, belonging to the Parties and Members of the said Company, in the Schedule hereunto annexed, the chief Fomentors, Con∣trivers, and Abettors of these unjust and horrid proceedings; requiring you John Hetherington, and you Lorenzo Zuma, or one, or both, or either of you, by the help and means of that officer sent by the Vizier, and those commands in your hands (beeing now at Smyrna, on other like occasions) according to your instructions herewith sent, to board and enter all Ships and Vessels, and to break open, and enter into all and every of the Houses, Ware-houses, Counting-houses, of all and every of the Parties in the Schedule hereunto annexed and aforementioned; and there to attach' arrest, take into your cu∣stody and possession; and as arrested and sequestred, to take, carry away, and put into safe custody, all such Monies, Mer∣chandizes, other Goods and Faculties of what nature soever that you shall discover, finde out, and get into your power, belonging to any of the Parties, or under the marks in the Schedule annexed; and the same to keep so arrested and seque∣stred, for our better indemnity, satisfaction, and defence a∣gainst all pretences of the Levant Company before mentioned whatever, untill wee may bee heard therein by due cours of Law, and till further Order from us in that behalf; for which this is to bee your Warrant.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Dated in Pera of Constantinople, this 30th of April, Anno 1646.
CLOSER.SALUTE: To our very loving Friends and ser∣vants, John Hetherington, and Lorenzo Zuma.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.HEAD: Warrant and Instructions for Lorenzo Zuma Our Drugger∣man (upon refusal of that Leviation which by Vote of Court here, bearing date the 18th of February last past, and Our Order thereon bearing dale the 28th of the same) sent with Orders and the Grand Seigneurs Imperial Commands to Smyrna, to raise and return into Our Cancellaria such part of that Leviation which conformable to the said Act of Court is made payable by the several Factors there, according to the Schedule therewith sent, and hereunto annexed, as followeth; viz.
DIV2.P: 1. UPon your arrival at Smyrna, you shall repair to the present Consul there, and tender him Our general Letter to the Nation, desiring him to call a Court thereon, and caus it to bee there read and published; the Copy where∣of, for your better information, you shall herewith re∣ceiv.

2. If thereon and according to the Contents thereof the Consul and every of the Nation respectively, shall either forthwith pay into your hands their and every of their re∣spective parts, or for every of them apart, give into your hands and possession good caution by a sufficient pawn with∣in twenty daies next following the delivery thereof in Court, to pay or cause to bee paid into our Cancellaria here his and their and every of their respective summs of money and proportions in the Schedule hereunto annexed, together with that charge which either hath or may ensue their late denial and refusal to make good the same, you shall there∣with rest contented untill Our farther order and direction upon their or either of their performances or failings, (as it may after fall out) which you are there to attend and expect from us in such occasion.

3. Or in case all or any of the said Factorie, in stead of paying his or their respective parts of the Leviation into Our
Cancellaria as aforesaid, shall bee desirous to give you Bills of Exchange for his or their respective parts to bee paid into the hands of the Companies Treasurer here, for the present time beeing, to bee disposed of by him to the uses aforesaid. In such case also you have power to comply with the Nation or any of them so desiring it, for his or their better ease and commodity; however, understanding nevertheless, that you first have such caution put into your hands for performance as before limited; viz. to the value of the said money, and one third part more for defraying of charges and casualties in occasion, and this pawn to bee in solid and Merchantable goods.

4. In case the said Consul and Nation or either of them after these offers, shall refuse or delay either to pay unto you, or to give you good caution (as aforesaid) by pledg of Cloth or other good Commodities to one third at least more than the value of what they stand rated in the Leviation afore-mentioned, & for the due payment of their and every of their respective parts & proportions thereof: In such case (ta∣king the Chouz along with you) you shall forthwith repair to the Caddie, and by the said Chouz his hand deliver such Commands to him (to bee Registred by him and after return∣ed unto you) as accompanie these, for your better aid to the effects aforesaid; and thereafter (for the Caddies greater awe, and the firmer securing him to the service and your part) you shall also in occasion shew him that Fettfaw which you here∣with receive, decling our absolute interest and Authoritie by the Grand Signors grant, and so, by their Law in such ca∣ses, over all His Majestie's Subjects under Our Charge, and thereon require the assistance of his power and aid according∣ly agreeable to the Imperial Commands in that behalf; for the procuring whereof to such ends as you are directed, and in such way and manner as may bee requisite (according to such occasion as may happily bee given you) you are not to spare any reasonable Cost or Change to make him firmly yours, and so his Naipe, or any other of Interest about him.

5. Having made the Caddie yours; for your farther help,
doubting the coloring, concealing, lading aboard som ship in Port, or otherwise misdisposing of such parties Estates in others Names, for prevention of deceit and abuse therein, you shall strictly prohibite all and everie of his Majestie's Subjects whoever, so refusing and delaying, the lading of any Goods, Money, Merchandize or facultie upon any English ship in Port, as also all and every of the English ship's Commanders and Officers whoever, belonging to such ships as then shall bee in the Port of Smyrna, to forbear taking in any of the Goods, Money and Merchandize belonging to any one of that Factorie, refusing and not complying in his or their part of the Leviation in manner aforesaid: Agreeable here∣unto, and the Commands in your hands, procure the Caddies signification to the Customer of the Scale, and his best assi∣stance therein, giving in the Names of such person or per∣sons as withstand the Leviation, and are refractorie to Our Orders.

6. In farther prosecution hereof, having first made the Caddie sure (as before, any refusing) you are (together with the Chouz, and som Officer of his) first to repair to the house or houses of him or them that shall make denyal of their parts of the said Leviation, and for the avoiding of noise (what you may) once more require it at every one of their houses privately and respectively; and upon his or their refusal whoever by the Chouz, to attach and arrest the Person or Per∣sons of him or them refusing or delaying, and the same keep in safe Custodie until Our farther order.

7. If thereon and after this, any one of them shall refuse or but delay to pay or to give you caution as aforesaid, you shall (together with the Chouz, and by the means and assi∣stance of the Caddie) enter into the house or houses, Ware∣house or Ware-houses, Counting-house or Counting-houses of all and every of such parties denying, resisting, refusing or delaying in one or either of the respects aforesaid (first ob∣serving the most material cause, most refractorie and so the fittest person to deal with) and (having before-hand provi∣ded sufficient and convenient Room or Rooms according to
the occasion in some good safe place or Cane therefore) you are to arrest, seize and take into your power, possession, carry away, and (until farther Order thereon from Us) lay up and put in safe custody so much of the Estate or Estates in Money, Silk or Silk-stuffs, or other like goods or faculties, as shall upon a reasonable estimate in value amount unto his or their parts and proportions refusing or delaying, (as afore-mentio∣ned) with an over-plus of one third part more in value, to∣wards that charge which hath been occasioned or may ensue by his or their refusing whoever, and not complying with the said Act of Court for the Leviation, and Our Order there∣on aforesaid.

8. In case the said Consul and Nation or either of them shall hereon notwithstanding withstand the Chouz and Cad∣dies Autoritie in such way or by such means of Force or o∣ther Combination to such a resistance as that thereby danger to the life of any may bee likely to ensue, if you should pur∣sue Our Commands herein as directed; or that you finde the Caddie or Chouz in such case, or other, scrupulous to proceed in the waies and to the effecting of Our Order in this behalf, without more special order from the Port, or for other re∣spects whatever: In such case you shall forthwith dispeed one of the Chouze's Servants and other Mess-express, with Arze to the Port, and your Certificate to Us of the manner of such resistance, and cause or causes of the hinderance of your proceedings, and in the mean respite your progress therein, and sit quiet until farther Order from Us and the Port in that behalf.

9. In all and every the particulars afore-going, and all other your Lawfull Endeavors therein, agreeable to such oc∣casion as shall or may bee given you in pursuance, and for your better execution of the premisses and every part thereof, These are as well to bee your Warrant as Instructi∣ons.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Given at Our Residence in Pera of Constantinople, the 30th April 1646.
CLOSER.SIGNED: SACKVILE CROW.

DIV2.HEAD: The particular Consignment of 6280 Broad Clothes landed at Smyrna out of the Ships Sam∣pson, Smyrna-Merchant, and Hercules, Rated at 8 Dollars ¾ per Cloth.
DIV2.CLOSER: Concordat cum Original. DOMENICO TIMONE Secretar.

DIV2.HEAD: Sir Sackvile Crow his Instructions to John Hethrington, dated in Pera the 30th of April 1646. For the execution of the aforesaid Warrants, with a Schedule of the nams of such men whose Goods hee chiefly aimed at, by a mark in the Margin.
DIV2.P: BY those Instructions wee have given to Lorenzo our Druggerman, in which wee send you as Assistant, and Superintendent, you will finde that wee have given him Or∣der (under color of the Leviation in hand, taking advan∣tage of their former refusal) to require either the money, and each mans part thereof respectively to bee paid into his hands there in specie, (which I conceive they are not able, or at least with their conveniency cannot, and so will not do,) or give him Caution by some good pawn (as in those Instru∣ctions) to a greater value; viz. one third part moe at least, for the payment of the money here, which you are to endea∣vour to see observed, or cause that course to bee taken there∣in, which is directed by Us in Our said Instructions to Loren∣zo; viz. upon their refusal, by means of the Chiouz and Cad∣die, to apprehend the chief and most refractory, and seal up the Ware-houses of them that have most Estate and Goods, and those chiefly aimed at, whose names you shall finde mark∣ed in a list of Names, and Schedule hereunto annexed, with a mark agreeable to that in the margin.

2. You are to be carefull that no creature know any part of your design; and sure not to be Courted by good fellowship, or other shew of friendship to you, or us, by discourse tou∣ching the ends of your coming or otherwise to make the least discovery, that may give intimation, or light of your inten∣tions. To any demanding of you the reason of your coming down; you shall say (as true it is) that you are sent to bee a spectator, witness, and overseer, of the Druggerman and
Chiouz proceeding in the Leviation, which they came about, and which so much concerns mee, them, and the publick in∣terest, and that that bee not bawked, or delaid, and that I might bee sure, to have the better intelligence from time to time of theirs, and the Nations procedings and accordingly (this beeing the first part of your service) you are to carrie your self; and as you are to perswade the Consull and Na∣tion on the one side, with reasons civil, and fair terms; so on the other you are ro urge the Druggerman, and Chiouz to provoke (or procure the Caddie, as occasion of resistance shall bee offered) to do their offices.

3. Whil'st you are laboring in this fair way, to these ends, and before you discover either too much passion, or eager∣ness, in pursuit thereof, or ought of your farther purposes, you must by all possible means and wayes seek to discover, what Goods and estate, each of the Nation (especially those before mentioned) have in their houses, and Magazeens, or carried abroad. viz. and principally Drugs, Cotten, and Gro∣graine yarnes, and more especially Silke, and Cloth: for the better knowledg whereof, you are to send som Armenian, or Jew Broker about, under colour and pretence of buying or bartering, for som Cloath, who by that advantage my enter their Ware-houses, and take notice what cloth or other Commodities they have, and where; and thereby give you light how to begin, and to proceed in your work to purpose.

But (as before directed) you are not to stir in the Second Warrant, untill the first have taken place, and you see the issue of that for the Leviation, on which if they pay you money there into the hands of Lorenzo, (which as before will bee impossible for them) your work will bee so much the easier, that money will serve mee as well: if they cannot pay, but offer your Bils without caution by pawn, you are not to take that, nor to accept any personall security, no not all the Nation for one of them, but in such case to proceed to a sei∣zure, and then bee sure you seiz enough, and all you can fasten on, especially of those men under the marks before mentio∣ned. But if they com to give Bills for the Money, which is
the thing you must chiefly press for, and will bee most like∣ly to be obtained; then those Goods so pledged and deposited (and for that purpose resting in your possession untill their Bills bee paid) will bee a sit subject for your other Warranr to work on, and (if there should after bee occasion of additi∣on) the rest would the more easily be found out and brought under; for which end, upon such seizure or pawn as before directed, you are to send us advice by express of the nature, condition, and quantity of such things as shall bee either ren∣dred you for a pawn, or seized by you, and what remaines of that parties besides, which if it bee in Cloth (and no o∣ther offer to bee had) you may take that at 45 Dollrs per Cloth, and so all other Commodities at a like under value, and after that rate ⅓ more then the value of each man's part in the Leviation (as in Lorenzoe's instructions) towards expen∣ces down for charges, suits of Law, casualties in sale, &c. that may ensue.

5. In case none of the two propositions take place with the Nation touching the Leviation, viz. either for payment of money there, or by Bills of Exchange, with security by pawn (wherein you are to know that the Law is on your side, and giv's you liberty to take what security lik's you, or refuse what like's you not) and that you bee thereby driven by way of force to make a seizure (which I doubt you will bee) In such case by means of the * Chiouz and * Caddie (as in Lorenzoe's in∣struction) you must first seize the persons most refractory, or most usefull to your occasion, into the Chiouz's hands; and keep them safe from communication with any other of the Nation; then seal up their, and every of their Ware-houses refusing; and after break them, and every of them open, and thence at your leisures, take out and carry, into som Cane or Canes first prepared by you, so much Silk, Cloth, Grograin, or Cotten-yarn, Druggs, Wax, and other like Merchantable Goods as you shall finde, and may amount to the value of his part of the Leviation so refusing; with ⅓ part more, as before; and the same shall keep so arrested and seque∣stred untill farther Order from us in that behalf; into what
Ware-house soever you enter, taking-precise notice and ac∣compt, as well what Goods you leav behind you, as what you take away, of which you are to give us punctual advice by express, for our better Government in what wee may bee occasioned farther to order and direct you, in execution of your second Warrant, after wee shall see the issue of the first.

6. For your better means to effect these ends, you must bee carefull, and as much as in you lyeth, and before you begin ought, by Friends, Presents, Money, or els, first to make the Caddie sure to you, and so his x Neipe, and those in credit with them, whether of his houshold▪ or in the Town; and especially amongst those of the Town, Bustangees and Aga; and having them with you, and beeing backed with those Commands and that Fettfaro, which you have in your hand; you need not doubt of prevailing over the other or any op∣posing you, the chief and principal beeing settled, whom you may confirm yours, by telling them that the Trade, and so their good is concerned, advantaged and protected by the Ambassador, and his care thereof, whose proper work that is, and that power given him by the Capitulations, and the Grand Signors express commands now sent with Fettfaro thereon; declaring that all our Subjects should obey our Orders accordingly, without which it would bee impossible to have any Trade continued here or there, or they have any Commerce or benefit thereby, there beeing none almost now but English that Trade, and that must also fail if their publick Debts bee not paid.

7. For this purpose, you are to spare no charge, whatever it cost; wee resolving to make the Estate of such as resist, to pay the expence, as well as our demands; and therefore you are well and diligently to observ the proceeding of the Cad∣die, and working of the Nation with him, or the Town; and accordingly, and with a diligence proportionable, ply your business.

8. For the better effecting whereof, considering your self and the Druggermen as strangers to the forms of that place, and
that those of the Nation may bee false to you; and to the end you may not bee to seek, as well for means to com ac∣quainted with the Caddie and other chief men of the place in occasion, nor how to discover our Merchants Estates and proceedings, nor to have a constant intelligence on them, or want help in occasion; you shall make use of such Letters as you will have from the French Ambassador, and our self, to the French Consul there, praying the Astance of his Drug∣germen in your occasions; under which geneals, having Or∣der from the Consul for his Druggermen in such occasion, beeing a Jew, you may for money (which you are not to spare) make him yours, and work him to your ends; but bee carefull (however) you trust him not with any secret, or discover the least particular and private part of our instructi∣ons; onely, that you are sent by my order, and the consent of the Nation here, for a Leviation towards som publick Debts and occasions belonging to the whole Nation; and doubting that som of them for avoiding payment, might go about either to conceal their Estates, or make opposition; as one Ambassador ought to do to another (in like case) I have desired the assistance of their Druggerman, doubting the fidelity of our own in a case wherein they are more de∣pendant on their own Merchants; by this means you will not onely enable your self by an experienced help, but take him off from joyning with and serving our Factors, and op∣posing or hindering you with the Caddie, &c. and beyond this, hee is not like to bee of great use to you; except happi∣ly (finding him like to proov faithful, and to promise fideli∣ty) you can by Money make use of him for discovery of the Merchants Estates as before, or making the Townsmen ca∣pable of the grounds and reasons of this payment, and our present Order therefore; if so, you will not onely leav the Factors without a party, or other defence, against our Au∣thority, and the Grand Signors Commands (which I must expect they will endeavour by all means possible to them, in in the waies of resistance, faction, or bribing to avoid) but help to bring in their Estates also discovered; in both you
will have this advantage, that what ever you give, come's out of their main stock; and so you may spare the less.

9. I hope the Customer before your arrival will bee a little calmer, then hitherunto hee hath been, and at last forsake the Merchants part; if not, you shall do well on your first arri∣vall, as on your old score of friendship, under colour of a visit, to make him sensible, not onely of those curtesies I have formerly don him, but to let him know how sensible I am of such his proceedings, and how contrary they are to his pro∣mises and oaths to mee, in case I could get him to bee made Customer of that place; at last, and in extremity, that if hee persist, you have power sufficient to curb him, or send him to Constantinople; and see first before you com to action, how that language will work with him.

10. If this take no effect to make him yours, (which I wish, if possible) you may tell him, hee can but expect a Custom for those Goods, which are ready to bee transported; and that whether those Goods go by these Ships or Land, hee shall have that, and a present to boot; conditionally hee suffer no Goods to pass by day or night, but such as hee shall have your or my allowance and note for, under your hand; where∣in if hee will assist you, that is, to deteign such Goods as I shall have occasion to attach and arrest; for all such as you arrest, you have power upon his performance of his part, to give him Bills for, payable by mee to the import of whatever they shall amount unto in Custom, together with such present to him therefore, as you and hee can agree for.

11. In case this will not serv his turn, you are then to proceed by the Caddie, to mak Aze to the Port, of his demeanure; lea∣ving the prosecution of him, and his demeanure hereto us, in that way shall bee fitting his carriage, and our duty there∣in; towards the procuring of which Arze in occasion, and to make it such as may take hold on the said Bogus, or any of his Abbettors or Assistants, Friends, Servants or other Mer∣chants, his Majesties Subjects, or of the Subjects of the Grand Signor, or any strangers whoever, that shall bee ayding or
assisting of any of his Majesties Subjects, in contra to our law∣full Orders aforementioned, (grounded on his Majesties Au∣thority, the imperial Capitulations, and Grand Signors Commands agreeable thereunto) you are to spare no cost: but whatever you do that way, must bee private, and to bee sure with charge.

12. Thus having latitude without limit to procure our just ends in manner before prescribed, as you are carefully to intend the matter committed to your trust; so you are dis∣creetly and with moderation to attend for sit time, and ob∣serv our directions in the series and succedency for manner of your proceedings; not absolutely limiting you, however therein, but (not having opportunity, first timely to advise us at this distance, and as otherwise might bee necessary in such case) observing and taking a fair and probable way to the main end you go for; wee leav you at liberty to do what shall appear most requisite; nevertheless willing you to ad∣vise us of all such digressions, and alterations in your pro∣ceedings, with the causes thereof, by expresses from time to time, and on all occasions; that thereon wee may govern our selves, and direct you as may bee most requisite for effe∣cting of that you go about, with Honour to his Majesty and safety to our selves.

13. That Letter you carry with you to Mr Lancelot, will shew you and him the caus why I desire not to make use of his hand in this particular; it agreeing best with his own desire to bee spared in it; however if hee stand not inclined to the Leviation, and to farther it, at least comply therein for him∣self and his proportion, and stand neuter for the rest; the first man you are to begin withall must bee hee, whose person though as beeing Consul wee will not have you attach untill our further order (except in case of resistance) yet you shall enter into his Hous and Warehouses, as being a Marchant withall, and there seize, sequester, and take away, as in any other man's case, in the manner, and to the ends afore spe∣cified.

14. But if you perceiv that the Nation have conveyed away a∣ny
considerable part of their Estates, that they stand resolute in denyall of the Leviation, or refuse to give caution there∣fore as directed, or doubt any sort of combination amongst them to those ends; and finde that Mr Lancelott, hath either connived with them or any of them in sending any Goods a∣board any of the Ships in Port, since our order of the 26 of January past, or to have sent any of his own Estate or others; you shall forthwith in such case, make use of the warrant to that effect, now also delivered into your hands, and for that especial purpose; and thereon caus the Chious to seiz, take into his power and safe custody, the bodies and persons of the said John Lancelott Consull, and six or eight more of the chief of the Nation, that you shall finde to have any hand therein, or shall refuse the Leviathan, viz. Daniel Edwards, Sam. Barnardiston, James Moyer, Henry Davis, or John Ball, John Pixley, &c. and seal up their Houses, Warehouses, and Magazines, till farther Order from us: But if you shall have any just caus given you to suspect the conveying of any goods out of their Houses, Warehouses, after such entry, sei∣zure, and you sealng up of their Houses, &c. before such advice can come unto us, and wee return you answer, and give farther directions therein; in such case, and as be∣fore directed, in the cases aforementioned, you shall enter the Warehouses of the said parties, take accompt of Goods and Estate there; and then by inventory take into your posses∣sion, and carry away the same, and every part thereof, espe∣cially fine goods, to some other safe place provided by you beforehand to such purpose; and there keep and detain the same until our farther order; and the other grosse Goods keep sealed up till then.

15. In case you should find Porter the master of the William & Thomas, not gone from Smyrna, nor apprehended by the Chi∣ouz sent down before your arrivall for that end; you must use all possible means to get him into your power, and the hands of the Chiouz now going with you, and send him a∣long with the rest; of the insolency of whose proceeding there (I mean of that escape there made by him first, and then
of the assault after by his Mariners) you must use all possible diligence to discover the truth with its circumstances, and which of the Nation were his Counsellors, Abettors or Assi∣stants therein; and thereof, and the particulars give us advice; as also, and especially, who have laded any Goods on his Ship, and to what value; whereof you are to demand ac∣compt for Mr Brent, and Mr Lancelot, and if they two bee found guilty, especially the Consull, bee sure to bring him up for one.

16. In the mean time you are to give strict charge by the Caddie to the Masters of the Ships, that none of them lade any goods on their, or either of their Ships, without fur∣ther Order; and sending the Consull, or other of the Mer∣chants, by some of the Chiouzes servants; and with the o∣ther Chiouz you are to stay with Lorenzo there, to make good the Estate, untill further Order from us upon advise.

17. In Case when you shall have entred any of the Merchants houses, and there seized of any of their Goods, or Estates, as Cloth especially, any Jew, or other shall com and pretend that that Estate is his, and bought of that Marchant; in such case after the proof of the particulars of his bargain before the Law, hee is to proov also, that hee hath paid the money for it; or els not having paid, when hee payes to receiv his goods, and untill then, the Estate to remain with you, or untill other Order by Justices which will require him to pay the money, or free the Goods.

18. For what concerns the strangers Consulage, after a day or two beeing there, you are to tell Mr. Lancelot, and Mr. Brent, that according to their promise, I have long expected the ac∣compt of particulars from them, and the Tariffe by which they use to rate goods in Consulage; which you are to de∣mand at first, and to expect, with some shew of civility for a while.

19. If they say they have sent it, or intend to send it to mee, you may tell them it was part of your Errand thither, to look a little into the manner of the carriage of that Busi∣ness,
and that you are to desire of them the sight of the Ma∣sters Entries, thereby to see how those Entries agree with the accōpt sent me; having perused these, you shal desire to see their Book by which that accompt is made up (which, if they have dealt sincerely with mee, they will not bee scrupulous to shew you, freely, if not you are to demand it by force; according as you shall finde the Books of Accompt, or their clearness You may tell them what I have heard touching a difference between themselves, and desire to see that accompt which they thereon referred to Captain Hurlstone, Master of the Society; if they refuse that, you are to Seal up their Counting-houses, and advise mee accordingly.

20. You may chuse as you see occasion, whether you will speak ought with Mr. Lancelott, touching his accompt of Consulage, till hee bee in hold, touching the other business (as I presume you will have occasion to put him) especiall-for his own lading, on the Ship William and Thomas, and suf∣fering others to do the like, after order from us, commands from the Port, and a letter from the Captain Bashaw prohi∣biting it; wherein finding Mr Lancelott an actor, you are not to spare him of all others, but bee sure to put him into the the Chiouzes hand, as false in, and guilty of all that con∣fusion and combustion, which hath happened by lading, con∣cealing, and conveying away of their Estates, which you will finde to have been hatched, and acted there: And in such case also to take hold of ought you can finde of his or Brents, for they are partners, and so interessed alike; for which, and whatever you shall do, upon the grounds against the persons, and conducing, and in the manner to the ends afore directed, these are to bee your warrant.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Given in Pera of Constantinople, this 30. of Aprill, 1646.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow.
Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Sir Sackvile Crow's Warrant to prohibite English ships to lade or depart.
DIV2.P:
VVHereas wee have heretofore in the name of the Grand Signor been required by the Vizier, to will and command that none of the ships of his Majesties sub∣jects whatever, coming into the Ports of Constantinople or Smyr∣na, should depart; or any ship coming into the Port of Smyr∣na should lade or take aboard them any Goods or Merchan∣dize, or bee dispeeded thence, until licence from the Port, and our order thereon and in that behalf: And whereas the said pleasure of the Grand Signor, aswell by his own Imperial Commands, as by the Capt. Bassa's letters, and our Orders thereon, have been signified to the Consul and Nation at Smyrna, and to the several Masters of ships there; And that yet som of them still continue lading, and notwithanding have since such Order and Command, dispeeded som ships from that Port, to the hazard of the lives and fortunes not only of them that have so laden & been aiding to the dispeed∣ing of such ships, but thereby given scandal to the sincerity of his Majesties friendship, and such jealousies thereon, as (in these times of Warr and Difficulties) may endanger a rupture between the Kingdoms, divers of the ships of his Ma∣jesties subjects at present being joyned with the Venetian Fleet; and actually in consort with them, lying and attend∣ing at the mouth of the Hellespont, ready to give the Grand Signor's Fleet battel at their own doors, and issue out of ther Ports. You are hereby required once more strictly to inhi∣bite, and in his Majestie's name to charge and command all & every of his Majestie's subjects, Masters of ships riding in the Port of Smyrna whoever, to forbear taking on board their or either of their ships or vessels, any Goods or Merchandize for the account of English or other whoever; and that they depart not the said port, untill wee shall bee able to procure
and signifie other and further order in this behalf; as also to signifie unto and require all and every of his Majestie's sub∣jects residing in Smyrna as Factors or others, that untill such licence and signification as aforesaid, they and every of them forbear to lade or cause to bee laden on any such ship or Ves∣sel that now is or may hereafter come into the said Port within the time aforesaid, by themselvs or any other direct∣ly or indirectly, any Goods, Merchandize and other Estate whatever; as they and every of them doing the contrary will answer it, and the dammages that may ensue at his and their utmost perils; and if any of them, Masters of ships or Factors, or other his Majestie's subjects whoever, after publication or notification hereof before witness, shall refuse to obey and do contrary to this Our Order, or any part thereof, you shall proclaim him and them and every of them (so disobeying and doing) Rebels, and out of his Majesties protection; and thereon signifie his or their and every of their names to Us; to the end wee may proceed against them and every such ac∣cordingly. For which this is to bee your Warrant.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Dated in Pera of Constantinople this 6th of May, 1646.
CLOSER.SALUTE: To Our very loving friends and Servants John Hethering∣ton and Lorenzo Zuma, or either of them.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Sir Sackvile Crow's Letter to Jo. Hetherington in Smyrna, May 7. 1646.

LETTER.P:
I Have this day received Letters from Smyrna of the 22. and 25. of April, finde thereby that Porter was not then de∣parted;
that the Chouz with the Druggerman were arrived; that all they or Mr Lancelot had done, was by a Letter rather to send him away than summon him, for ought I can discern to the contrary: wherein hee had intimated to him the Grand Signor's pleasure and my Order for his stay. In fine a piece of the old story, others not beeing to bee expected from one so deeply interested in the others lading. In conclusion, I finde Jorden come into that Port also unladed, and to have contra∣cted for his lading there, without regard to his promise or my ingagement for his lading here; and that also by Mr Lancelott's perswasions, contrary to the others own resoluti∣on, (as his Letter relate's) the meaning whereof can bee no other, than that hee and the Nation have been work∣ing, whil'st hee hath endeavoured to make mee believe other∣wise; viz. the carrying of all out of the Countrey, and de∣feating the Leviation, &c. for that's the very language of the Nations meaning, whil'st they desire 4 moneths time yet for payment, (as those that have advice of that resolution pretend and say); but I have not yet received their general Letter, though divers Copies thereof are come to Town, which is a Riddle also.

Upon the premisses I shall not finde cause to alter any part of your Instructions, but second it in all as well form as mat∣ter; viz. First to proceed with that business of Porter and his Laders, to clap them up and make them and their Estates sure, as directed; then to proceed to the Leviation; and af∣ter to let the other fall in of cours, and take it's place in time. Only one Caution I shall think good to add, that in case there bee not or you cannot get a resolution for the Levia∣tion by a general consent in Court, with a Pawn for pay∣ment, in such manner as is directed; you need not trouble your self with that, but according to that List and Schedule annexed to the Order for Leviation, proceed to a sequestra∣tion and possession of every mans particular apart, not regar∣ding the Consent of the whole, by staying or looking to an Act of Court of their assent there; for you must know that this is an Order for execution, and an Act of Justice, procee∣ding
from mee as his Majestie's Commissioner, and you are to govern your self accordingly, and as men sent on such an Errand; and nt to treat or capitulate beyond your Istructi∣ons, and so you are to let those people know in occasion.

Mr Edwards hath given order for his part of the Leviation money by Mr Piggot; who even now make's tender of it to mee, and happily will think much to bee arrested for that: But I take no notice of any such tender to mee in person; the first Order run's for payment into Cancellaria by such a day; your Order goe's for Leviation and Charges for non-payment there; and (believe mee) the Charges of their refu∣sal at Smyrna, must bee born by them of Smyrna, and not by mee or the Nation here. But leaving that dispute aside, (as a thing by the by) in case Mr Edwards should object this as a reason of his, for avoiding his part of the Charge, or for gi∣ving Caution; you may say that untill it bee certified to you, you can take no notice of it, neither spare him nor any o∣ther, but in the mean time are to proceed with him as the o∣ther: and over and above, in case hee should (notwithstand∣ing that Order of his before mentioned) bee contented yet to give in Caution by Pawn, as others are ordered to do, hee proving faulty in Lading the William and Thomas, you are to proceed with him according to your Instructions and Com∣mand to such effect; for (I confess) I long to have him in my power, of all men in Smyrna, having suffered by him more than by any one there, except one that you have advice of.

To conclude, taking all you have to do into considerati∣on, I finde you have a difficult part to act, and therefore you are to bee sure to take it by those degrees you are directed in, and to be sure to avoid the confounding of one thing with a∣nother, and in the last place to make your demand of Consu∣lage, &c. as by your last Warrant, but not that neither untill further Order, (I mean on the whole Nation).

And touching that, of Lancelott and his Companion, to proceed by degrees with them also, or rather than fail he and his Companion coming up (as I presume they will, if
not for the Leviathan, for having laded on the William and Thomas contrary to order) you may let that pass till their ar∣rival here (having first sealed up their Warehouses and count∣ing houses, as directed,) by the by however getting what advice you may touching their carriage of that business. And whatever you come to discover, shall act, or do; I pray advise mee from time to time, & daily, or every two dayes at the fur∣thest; for your intelligence will bee the onely rule for my future direction; not having further to add that I can think necessary at present I rest.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Pera of Constantinople, this 5th of May, 1646.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Your loving Kinsman and Master Sackvile Crow.

LETTER.P:
