I Have this morning by the Consuls Messenger received the Originall of the nations generall Letter subscribing to the Leviation, desiring respite of payment for five moneths time; to which I give that answer you will finde in the Co∣py of mine to the Consul herewith sent you; by which you will discern that I still drive the business to a Caution and pledg; and with all reason I may demand it, for by that time they may have conveyed away their Estates, or received som other order from England, and so frustrate the Leviation totally, & leav & the Nation here under the Debt and ingage∣ment; which you may let the Nation know I have no reason to admit of, and so not to contradict that order I have for∣merly sent, which is to demand your Caution for perfor∣mance: next (suppose they would now pay the full, actually in hand to my Druggerman, you are to say, you have not power to take that neither, without like security for the Charges of their former refusal; which what it is or may bee, by their contrasts ensuing, I have not been nor shall bee able to set down in particulars, untill I see the issue. Whatever it
may bee, they may bee sure as I seek noe advantage in that, so I am resolved not to loos by it, and lay money out of my purs for their defaults; So if they consent on these terms, give you good caution into your hands, to bee put apart by you into some place under your power, you may consent; and having done so expect my further Order thereon: other∣wise you are to proceed without more Ceremony in the way you were first directed; And so I once more leav that business, the rather findeing that the nation here will not bee otherwise satisfied with their assurance, for ought I can dis∣cern, by those I have hitherunto spoken with; resolving to morrow to call a Court, and then I am sure to finde this opi∣nion of theirs more confirmed, (as I am sure I must) when I shall demand all mine own monies, amounting one way or other to near 30000 dollars, to bee presently paid; and to say truth, I am not resolved to exspect much longer for it. You will by the inclosed see what I write to Captain Jorden, and if I might yet expect to finde him other then a Tarpawling, I could wish hee would yet take in such goods as might offer themselves at Smirna on this occasion, and come up to Constantinople therewith; from whence I would assure him as good a fraight, as ever hee had, better then hee can expect from any hand in Turkie without mee. If you finde him not too much otherwise ingaged, or changed to be round since I saw him; you may sound him to that effect, having first in your power sufficient to lade him with for this place: If hee refuse it; or accepting, give you not a chearfull assu∣rance to comply therein, you are not to suffer him or any other to lade, until further order from the Port and mee; but protest against the customer and Merchants whoever till they shall lade on him or the other ship in Port: If on this, for the better disguise of the business, hee will bee contented with a Warrant of mine to press him to this service, you shall have that also; and s, partly by denying his Lading there, on the one side; partly by Warrant and Command on the other, hee may seem to bee constrained, and so for avoid∣ing of greater Inconveniences, to embrace the of∣fer;
assuring him that in case his ship bring not up those goods another shall or a Carravan: If hee shall have taken in any goods of strangers (which hee pretends to bee in a treaty for) they may likewise be put onshore again, upon & under colour of command from mee to desist the voyage; and if need bee I shall send a Command from hence to that purpose also. If the Customer shall be brought to dispute the business, you may tell him other goods shall bee laden in the room, & those of stran∣gers on other Ships now coming down, & pay him as good a Custom or better, with a 2d advantage to his Patron here: wherein (if Jordan consent) you are not to be scrupulous to as∣sure the Customer, and so Jordan, som considerable advantage to themselvs apart and beyond their Ordinary way; and this still to bee carried under the Cover of Command from hence, and my order thereon; wherein (save in that to Jordan) you are already sufficiently Warranted. And for that also you shall with these have Warrant and Order, effectual to bee made use of in such occasion, as by the inclosed; viz, 1. a Warrant, a new prohibiting anv others lading: 2. A pro∣test against Jordan for not complying with mee; which never∣theless I would not have you use or drive to the extremity, untill further order, but seeming (as before that hee conti∣nues inclined to his Majesties service and not changed from his former profession, by and with his consent, as before di∣rected, to make use of them, as in publick to draw him to it, as it were by an outward seeming force; If hee dispute the loss of time, you may assure him, that it will not bee long but he shall have advice of an open Port and a freer seale here, then there; for the Gallies resolv and are Ordered to depart the Castles on Monday or Wednesday next, and then the issue of that business will bee quickly seen: the time hee shall spend in Demurrage between this and that, or her, shall likewise bee considered: which offers you must know, are ra∣ther out of som hope that Jordan may bee yet a little hone∣ster then his fellowes, (that is more likely to bee firm to mee in my design) otherwise finding him or having caus to su∣spect the contrary, you may let him go as hee is, that is to
say not trouble your self with looking after him or his E∣state much; onely hinder him and all others from lading un∣till I am Master of that I aime at; for upon your advice I shall make use of som one of these Ships here to transport my Wife and Family, and provide for the rest in time. God bless your proceedings, and my just endeavours to a lawfull defence. Whil'st I rest

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your loving Kinsman and Master Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.P: The manner of your proceedings with these Warrants must bee thus: First you must publish that for prohibi∣biting lading or receiving goods on board, as well to the e∣very of the Nations Houses, as to the Ships in Port, and not refuse any of them Copie; giving it into the Cancellary to bee registred, but taking back the Warrant to your self: af∣ter this you will have a fitter time to treat with Jordan, and an occasion to make use of the other Warrant for protesting against him.

DIV2.HEAD: John Hetherington's Letters to Sir Sackvile Crow, dated the 13 of May 1646. in Smyrna, of his proceedings to that time.
DIV2.P:
IN mine yesterday, (if arrived) your Lordship will perceiv how I did begin to dislke the Baluke: and truely, my Lord, not without caus, for except your Lordship had been an eye-witness to his proceeding, it will bee hard to imagine how basely covetous hee is; and yet if that would serv his
turn, having so large a Commission as your Lordship was pleased to afford mee, hee should not have been discon∣tented, though it had been to the whole of what I had brought down; which rather to let the world see how much you are abused by those that provide you these men, or to let a busi∣ness of so high a nature as this fall to the ground. But my Lord, I wish better to them, then to accuse or to blame any, onely my own hard fortune, that at my entrance into a busi∣ness of trust, I should proov so unhappy, and bee so much abused; For as I yesterday advised your Lordship by this ungratefull fellow, the Consul with six more of the chief, were rendred at Justice before the Caddie into the Balouke's hands; who prrsently brought them home, and according to your Lordships order, wee desired him to keep them close, and not to suffer any to com to have any discours with them, for prevention of som such design as was acted on Porter; and accordingly hee did, and nayled up the Windowes to the Chamber, and promised me to carry them away as last night himself, for stay hee would not; but after this, hee suffers the Consuls Druggerman to come and treat with him, and for a present of Dollars 100 caused the Windowes to bee ope∣ned, and suffered his srvant and twelv Soldiers that wee had from the Castle to guard them, to let in the Nation for a Dollar or two a head, as long as they would come. As soon as I discovered his waies of treaty with these people, I told him plainly, except hee would immediately send these people up to your Lordship, I must bee forced to send an express to your Lordship, to lament, and that your Lordship may have Justice above: but I could get no absolute answer from him; somtime hee would go, another time hee would dispute, that they proffered to pay their money, and for that end hee came; so wee were forced to let the Leviation stand a little at a stay, and to pretend those men conformable to that com∣mand in his hands, and were to bee sent up for lading of goods on the William and Thomas; and withall hath promi∣sed to give him when hee is ready t go, Dollars 500 more, if hee will bee carefull to see the business performed according
to your Lordships desire and express; and till your Lordship shall send another to assist us, wee will detain the Chiouz, sent with Jean Maria. The Balouke is now gon to the Caddie to take his Arze along with him, and at his return, I hope will either go himself, or send the Chiouz with them; but whether hee go or stay, I continue my humble request to your Honor, that with what possible speed and conveniencie your Lord∣ship may, to send us som new supply, or els to this good caus and just demands of your Lordship, in my weak opinion, your Lordship may for the present bid adieu to it.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Sir Sackvile Crow to John Hetherington and Lorenzo Zu∣ma, in Smyrna 25 May 1646.

LETTER.P: BOgus hath been with mee, and hath so humbled and assu∣red himself that I cannot but give him Credit once more; and you are thereon to take notice.
1. That hee hath promised, not to suffer either of the Ships in Port, to lade ought by day or night? untill farther order from mee, for strangers or others.
2. That untill then, none of the Ships there shall depart the Port.

1. On the other side I have given my consent and promi∣sed, that what goods soever are, or shall com consigned on a∣ny Ship to that place Inward; hee and you shall have full power to unlade and discharge their goods on shore.

2. That for his forbearance and not suffering any goods to bee laden on either of the Ships in Port untill order from mee as aforesaid; hee shall have his Custom for all goods alrea∣dy laden, or to bee laden; Hee the said Bogus declaring and ma∣king appear unto you for whose accompt the said goods either were, or should have been laden, and giving you Teskary for the lading of the lading of the same, as for goods that had been laden and paid their Customes.

3. That for all goods hee shall discover of the English Nations to bee hid and concealed from mee, in the hands,
Custody, or Ware-houses of any Jew or others, & shall proov to bee such, (that is to say (English goods, and to whom the said goods belong) hee shall have his Custome for all such goods, and upon Consignment thereof into your hands by order of Law; For which you have Commands also, as if the said goods were and had been laden and dispeeded the Port, giving Teskarie as aforesaid.
4. That over and above this, hee shall have a present to such value, as you and hee agreed on, and shall bee fitting his faithful complyance herein and his promises to

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your loving friend Sackvile Crow.

LETTER.P: I finde by Bogus, that hee make's scruple to receiv Custome for any goods which shall not bee put aboard the Ships, which hee pretends and would have mee believ hee shall bee better able to Master there then at Land: But I doubt him for this more then before; and for this caus have referred him to a Treatie with you below, and promised him, that what a∣greement soever you make with him there, I shall make good to him, and bee obliged unto here; hee promising to discover to you great things, and a vast Estate of the Nations in the Countrey yet left; which I wish hee may perform; but I doubt hee will proov a knave in all.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Yours as before Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.P: Wednesday next about noon the Chouz, with these Com∣mands necessary (Biza de Chouz whom Lorenzo knowe's) will set forward, and I hope in five daies after will bee with you.
You may see what I write to Captain Jordan, for his Letter is open, the seal volant for you, seal up when you have read it.

DIV2.HEAD: Sir Sackvile Crow his full approbation of what John Hethering∣ton, and Lorenzo had done; and his further Instructions to them how to proceed. Dated in Pera the 27 May, 1646.
DIV2.P: I Have seen and well weighed what yours of the 12th ad∣viseth, with that of the 13th, which came not to my hands before the arrival of the Balouke Bassac, with the Chiouz and their Company; who at their arrival made terrible com∣plaints of your severe proceedings with them, especially the Consul, who had prepared a learned Elogie; but I cut him off in the midst by a short approval of what you had done, and told them plainly 'twas no more than what I had enordered you, and that if you had done less, you must have seen mee no more. I told them I came not hither to bee made a slave for the Companies Debt; I had their Cove∣nant to see that paid by Leviation, and that Leviation agreed by their own, &c. bade them welcom to the trouble of their own procuring, and so left them for that present to a bet∣ter consideration, in the mean time put a guard upon them.

This morning (they having since Saturday had the liberty of my hous, and free conference with all that would come and go) they send mee a request as full of humility, as their first discours was of vapour; with promise to pay in their parts of the Leviation; whereupon they have liberty, with a Druggerman and Janizarie to go amongst their Compani∣ons at Gallata, to gather in their monies, but to return at night: Lancelott stayes still in the hous for the greater gra∣vity.

Yesterday I received yours of the 15 and 16, and to bee short, approov of all you have hithero done, with the mo∣deration and discretion you have used in the passages therof, taking due notice of the vile proceedings of that ill Servant
of the Viziers, and his Companion the Chouz; upon whose arrival, and receipt of your former, I prayed audience with the Vizier, and Saturday last obtained it; giving him thanks notwithstanding for the service don by his Balouke Bshe, acquainting him that som of those men were com, that o∣thers had hid themselvs and their Estates, and so prayed as in the Command you will see directd.

The Vizier gave mee as gracious an audience as ever I had in Turkie, and a further assurance of respects, then ever I had from any Vizier; with an assurance also of the Grand Signors esteem; which hee spake publickly, and with intent, as I con∣conceiv, to do mee Honor; which I the rather relate to you, to encounter that vanity I finde in that supposition mentio∣ned in the latter part of your last, touching what they either had, or might do towards you, that are but my instruments; wherein you may defie their utmost, as long as they them∣selvs have ought in Turkie, to purchase the contrary (if such occasion were:) but no more of this folly; wishing you also not to take farther notice of it, then to observ from what people, and what grounds this sort of language proceeded, or may hereafter bee like to bee voted, and to advise mee as you have done in this, leaving mee to provide for your safe∣ties. In the mean, for what may concern the farther eon∣duct of your business; you are to observ.
1. (As in your instructions) that you make the Leviation the ground-work of all your future work, for the better e∣stablishment of that Factory, as formerly inordered.

2. Next, being informed that that Factory, not onely for avoyding of the just Debts for the publick already contracted, but also for doubt of paying such expences as may bee neces∣sary for the support of the publick charge in future, have concealed much of their Estates, and intend to convey it and themselvs out of the Countrey, (as som of them of late have done) you are to use all possible diligence to discover what Estate of the Nations remaines yet in that Factory, in their own, or others possessions, the particulars, and to whom it belongs, to send mee a List in a Schedule, or (if not that)
as neer an estimate thereof as you can get; and in the mean time to take what care you may (agreeable to your former Commands and Warrants) that no part thereof bee trans∣ported, untill farther order from us in that behalf.

3. Whereas there are two English Ships in Port, expecting their fraight there; and that wee are informed they lade a∣way Goods of the Nations in strangers names, by connivance with the Customer, and his servants there in the night; you are strictly to prohibit the Masters of the said Ships to take in any Goods, especilly the Jonas bound for England directly, and the like Captain Jordan, who pretends to lade for Italy; and Strangers Accompts, but under that colour, to carry away the Nations Estates, before Order taken for our future subsi∣stance; intending thereby under pretences of the dangers of the times, to leav us destitute and naked of all future meanes of subsistance: For prevention of which (as well as to procure means for payment of the present Debt) you are chiefly im∣ployed, and are to apply your whole endeavours according∣ly; and (agreeable to your former Warrant and Instructions) if any of the Masters or Factors shall attempt ought in contra, untill our farther Order upon your future advice, and till wee bee better secured in the premisses, you shall declare against all such as Rebells; and apprehend all such persons whoever, and send them to us together with their accusuti∣ons, to bee proceeded against accordingly.

4. To secure your selvs the better against those doubts you make of the Captaines resistance; suspecting any such thing, and having discovered in whose hands they have any Estates, or for whose Accompts the Captaines, or either of them have any Estates on Board; you shall caus svch of their corespondents, and interested at Land, to give good caution and security for them and it, by pledg of other Estate, (for you are not to trust to any personal security insuch case whatever without a good and considerable pawn to the value, and proportionable to the doubts & occasions,) and for this and you are to look out carefully, for such Estate as Jordan, & the other have on shore in any of the Factors hands by way of
Hypothecation, or otherwaies; and what Goods or Estate any of those on shore, or here, have on board the Ships there; and to make attachment and sequestration thereof, to the said ends aforesaid, untill further Order from us in this behalf and if need bee, carry them before the Caddie to caus them comply with the Command, or stand committed into your own custodies and the Chiouzes.

5. What you have don to the Caddy, and his Servants, wee approv of, and desire you to continue him yours, and so all his, or any of the chief of the Town; whatever it cost you; for their better perswasion whereunto (besides what you shall give, or present on that occasion) you are to let them, and so the generality know, that the chief end of all this, is but to secure the Trade for the future; there beeing a design amongst many of them to carry, all out of the Coun∣trey, for fear (as they pretend) in these times of Warr, and to leav the Ambassador alone; And that our ends are (by kee∣ping a good Estate in the Countrey) to secure the peace, and continue the commerce; which you may boldly affirm, since my coming into the Countrey, (within these 8 years) is doubled well neer to what it was; and they see by my care it daily increaseth.

6. If any of the Nation after payment of their parts of the Leviation, or giving you caution therefore, should desire so to bee at liberty, to lade their other goods; you may not permit that, till further Order as before declared; And this for the reasons before specified, viz. That I must bee first secu∣red, in som reasonable measure from the Nation (which is now upon consult also here) how wee may subsist for the fu∣ture; or in default of the Companies performance, and going on with their Trade, may free, or secure my Hostages; and in the mean time, how my self, Secretary, Druggermen, and Officers may, or shall bee provided for.

7. For the better understanding hereof in publick, you may caus the Caddie, and so his people to divulge this, (as really it is) to bee (besides payment of their Debts,) the true scope, and chief meaning of this our strict care, and pro∣ceedings;
for better evidence whereof, you may observ to them the escape of som of our Merchants already, and the carriage of Porters ship, departed in the manner it did; and thereon you may say to them, that if I have not better obser∣vance or security from my people for the future, I shall bee ill able to answer for them to this State, or for their actions at home, or preserve the Peace, for which I am principally sent hither; for which, though the Merchants manage the Trade, 'tis I that govern and protect it, that have power to increase or diminish it.

8 Having the Commands you shall herewith receive, you are to desire the Caddie to publish to the Ships and Nation, and so likewise to give notice to the Customer, and all Offi∣cers about the Marine, That neither the Ships presume to take on board any other Goods, nor depart the Rode with those Goods they have, nor any English Merchant or other, whether of his Majestie's, or Subjects to the Grand Signor, or others, put on board any Goods or Merchandize whatever, on any English ship or Vessel whatever in that Port, untill our farther Order, agreeable to the Commands; wherein, and for effecting whereof, or discovery of the contrary, you shall not spare any cost whatever, to the Caddie or his Ministers, the Customer or his Servants, Jews, Waiters, Boatmen, or other Officers whoever by you used, or to bee used in the premisses.

9. What Money you shall want, you may take up either of the Customer, or other whoever (where you can finde it) and cause it to bee charged upon Mr South; for which the money is ready by mee, if it should bee for 10000. Dollars.

10. Lastly, if the Customers should make opposition, or scruple; you (as I formerly advised and secured you) may promise him his Custom for any Goods whatever you shall bee possest of by his means or discovery, with a Present to boot, and to his content; and then I know none have to com∣plain, but my Master's own Subjects, who by the Capitulati∣ons, Fettfaw, and Commands in your hands, ought to bee under, and subject to my Judicature onely, in things de∣pending
between themselvs, or relating to my Govern∣ment.

11. Bogus, since my writing thus farr, hath been with mee twice; but hee is either such a fool, or such a knave, or both, at least so unconstant, that I finde no great likelyhood of certainty in him; so have left him to you to treat and con∣clude with him there, as you shall finde occasion, and bee fit∣test for the service; as by the Postscript in the Copy of that Letter given him for you and Lorenzo.

12. I long to hear in particular what you have discover∣ed and found out; at least an estimate of the value of that you may suppose to finde there, and to whom belonging; which I desire with the first opportunity to bee advised of. Bogus pretends much that way, and I wish hee may discover what hee promises, and (whether true or no) saies, that little of that which remains in their own Warehouss belongs to the Merchants, but to Turks, and Jews, &c. and that all or the greatest part of their Estates is conveyed into Turks, Jews, and Armenians hands; thinks that the best way to make a true discovery, and to get possession of the right (assoon as the Nation had given satisfaction to the Leviation) would bee to make a shew of retiring and going away, and to stay a daies journey or two out of the Town, and that thereupon they would soon bring back all their Goods to their own Houses; but at this distance I cannot so well direct you, nor otherwise, than upon receipt of those Commands I now send you, to seize what you can first, and after watch the rest as wall as you may; and so secure something to Us for a future bring; for Wee are now on the Stage, and must through with it, or (for ought I discern of their good wills) want a beeing here another day: these people, as fast as they can, packing and conveying all away; and for the present also (with such difficulties as you see) contending the payment of their own debts; not caring to leave Us, and our Hostages, Servants, Secretarie, Druggermen, and all, destitute in this savage place; without the remorse of men, less of Christians, which they hardly appear to bee.

13. Bogus at his parting from mee, gave mee assurance, that (in case I would) hee could and would take from the Masters of Ships there their Sails and Rudders; but I would not as∣sent to that, without your approbation therein; who by beeing on the place, will bee better able to judg of the possibi∣lities, conveniency, or inconveniencies of such an attempt; nor would I advise it, but in case of extremity, or upon a just suspition of some design to send away the Ships, or upon proof of their Lading contrary to Order, by night or other∣waies, whereof you are to bee carefull; and in occasion (see∣ing Bogus give way to the Ships lading, or the Ships lade con∣trary and without him, (as lade yet I hear they do) and un∣der the colour of Strangers names endeavour to convey all away) you shall repair to the Caddie for counsel and help, and take license and Order from him, with some of mine and his people to watch by boats in the night, and thereby the better secure their future endeavours; for which you need not spare any reasonable cost to the Caddie or Waiters; and therein I am confident Bogus will not oppose, but farther you; if hee do not, upon the least advice I shall begin anew with him.

14. For your better assistance yet, and to the endl may leav no way unthought of, or you unwarranted or undirected to that end you go about; I have herewith sent you Warrant to require security of the Nation (especially those to whom any of the Ships in Port shall bee consigned, or any other you shall know to have estate of the Captaines in their hands, or to have laden on the said Ships) by pawn, to the value of their lading at least; and that the Captain or Captaines of the Ships shall not depart the place therewith without my leave and order; and in case any of them refuse so to do, you shall require their appearance before the Caddie, and there demand their Persons and Estates into your hands, especially of these Merchants and Traders left behinde, viz. Davis, the other Barnardiston, Inglesby, Ball, and such other of them as you shall finde busie in lading, or to have laden any considerable Estate on the said Ships, or to have any Estate of the Masters of Ships in their hands (the said Masters not complying and be∣ing
obedient to my Orders in manner as directed) wherein (as I wrote Mr Jordan yesterday) hee and the rest must pardon mee, if I value my self and Hostages, at least equally with them, if not before; and the Publick before any ones parti∣cular: however in due time shall have care of him, that, and the rest also, and all as becomes mee, if they will have but pa∣tience, and bee ruled by mee, discover what Estate they have on board, and for whose Accompts, &c. which doing, they shall see I will deal them that Justice in the conclusion, that they shall have cause to thank mee. But if by the perswasi∣ons of others for private ends, they steer a contrary cours: though Smyrna bee a great way off mee, they will finde by de∣grees, that I shall have means and power to reach them.

15. Even now I am advised, that there is another English Ship arrived about Smyrna; the name I hear not of, but that by advice from within, the Ship should ride without, and re∣solves for Scanderoon, and to discharge and take in her La∣ding there; for prevention, I hope to get you a command yet before the Chiouz depart, to secure that other corner also; least that outlet should bee more troublesom than the other.

16. Lastly, upon serious considerations, and by all I can judg of by the discourses, fears, and contrivements of this place; I conclude that your shortest and securest way to your end (upon finding the least appearance of the Masters jugling with you, or of the Ships lading or departing, and not having a true discovery of what is laden on each of them, and by whom; or finding any of the Nation underhand assisting or abetting in any way contrary to your Instructions) will bee to fall presently to work on them that move or resist you, as by your Warrant herewith sent you is directed; which agrees with the Command & my Opinion, which is, that by delaies, or a seeming retreat (at least untill what is discovered be made sure, and these Ships bee made render what they have of our Nation on them) we shall get little advantage by suspending; however leav all to your nearer Judgments, according to oc∣casion on the place, for which your Warrant is large enough. And so for the present I bid you farewell, resting

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your assured loving Friend SACKVILE CROW.
CLOSER.DATELINE: May the 27. 1646. from Pera of Constantinople.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Sir Sackvile Crow's Warrant to Jo. Hetherington and Zuma, forbidding the Lading of ships. 27 May, 1646.
DIV2.P:
VVHereas, wee are informed that notwithstanding se∣veral Imperiall Commands sent by the grand Seig∣nior, and declared by his Officers Chiouses and others, accom∣panied with our Orders, warrant, and directions thereon, requiring, (for severall weighty and important Causes) all and every of his Majestie's Subjects, and others whosoever to forbear lading of any Goods or Marchandise on any English Ship or vessel within the Port or Scale of Smirna, or mem∣bers thereof, and all and every such Ship or ships, vessel or vessels, to forbear taking any such goods or Marchandise on bord them for accompt of any whoever, and not to depart the said Port or members, without express Order and Licence from the Port and Us, in that behalf, (the Visier declaring us by severall wayes, as his Majesties Minister, accomptable therefore) wee are certified, how by the Combination of some of our Nation with the Customer there, two or three shipps have been already dispeeded thence full laden, and two or three ships more rest there yet lading and near laden, & ready to set sail and depart; and thereby leav us to answer such their Contempt and demeanor as wee may; without the least regard to his Majesties honor or Interest by Capitu∣lations with this State, or the safety of us, or the rest of those of his Majesties Subjects, who are to remain in the Country. These are to pray and require you immediately upon receipt hereof, by all possible diligence to make enquiry after, search out, demand of the Commanders and Officers of the ships, or finde out by the Customer or other wayes, what Goods are laden on either of the English ships now in the said Port, what quantity of Goods and Merchandize, and to whom the same belongeth; at least by whom and in whose names laden: And having found out and discovered the same, to make and cause the said parties (to your selves, or in default by the
Caddie) to give caution for the stay of the said Ships; viz. that they shall not depart that Port, untill further from this Port and us in that behalf; And in the mean time you are to require the said Captains not to give any Bill or Bills of Lading, to any of the parties that have so laden any goods upon their said Ships: as they will answer the con∣trary at their perils: And if any of the Masters shall be re∣fractory therein, and refuse to declare unto you all and every the particulars of such goods and Merchandize as shall bee la∣den by them as aforesaid, or shall not forbear to give Bills of Lading therefore, or shall not forbear further lading of his or their ships; in vertue of the Commands now sent you, (and others in your possession) you shall attach and arrest the persons and Estates of the said Captains, and of all and every of his Majesties Subjects, who have laden ought on the said Ships, whether on bord the said ships or on shore, wherever or whatever to them belonging: And for the better Disco∣very and execution of the Premisses, together with and by the aid and assistance of the Caddie, in vertue of the said Com∣mands, you shall enter into all or any of the ships, houses, Warehouses or Counting houses; and there also seiz and take into your power and possession all Books of Accompts, Bills of Debt, Acquittances, Letters, or other Writings, E∣state, Faculty, or Evidence whatever you shall finde there, belonging to any of his Majesties Subjects whoever; and the same take into your possession, keep, peruse, and make use of in evidence or other waies, untill further Order from us in that behalf: for which this is as well to bee your Warrant, as for all other matters and things you shall do and execute in the lawful prosecution of the premises, or any part thereof.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Given at our Residence in Pera of Constantinople, this 27 May. 1646.
CLOSER.SALUTE: To our very loving friends and servants Jo. Hetherington, and Lorenzo Zuma, in Smyrna.
CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Sir Sackvile Crow's Letter to Jo. Hetherington. 28 May, 1646.
DIV2.P: HAving made an end of this dispatch near two daies since. I have stayed expecting, and untill this hour do, the Chi∣ouz; whom they pretend to stay for some Services of the Grand Signors, as they did the last: but I hope this day to get him dispacht, and so come to my private Instructions to your self:

1. Wherein (as in my Publique to Lorenzo and you, as also in your former) you are to make that of Publique shew its face outward, and to come first in Action; the first part of that pretence is now almost finished, I mean the Leviation for Past-Charges; and when that shall bee fully finished, I resolve to begin with Prouision for the Publique in future; taking into consideration the distractions of England, the War at our door here, the French forces before Ligorne: and by all these a likelyhood that wee may bee in an ill condition here, ere long: and therefore it will bee fit to look out in time, and provide some means at least, for future subsistence; wherein the Company stand obliged to the Crown of En∣gland by their Charter, and to mee by their Covenant to make Provision.

2. When this in hand is done, that other may bee taken order for; and in the interim, under the colour of the one and the other, the full of the Estate or most of it may bee dis∣covered; and after this, I shall have opportunity to bring in my own pretences, for which you have Warrant sufficient and particular with you already; and this latter Warrant now sent you, will serve you for the other two— and for∣mer part of the business, viz. for finding out, discovery, and securing what you finde until further Order, in what hands or place soever; However, I wish it by convenient degrees and steps, at least not findeing occasion to the contrary.

3. With the Merchants, in its time you may treat their
reason apart, viz. that this concerns their own preservation, as well as mine; and that they may be sure before any Estate more goes out of the Countrey, I will see at least how as well this, as that Scale may bee preserved; That a Factory, this a Residence, untill it may pleas God wee meet with better times.

With the Masters you may deal in another way, (if they or either of them deserv it,) viz. assure them a good and consi∣derable fraight, if they will but have patience; and so may happily also consider their demurrage, in case they behave themselves as they ought; on the other side they may bee sure, I will not overthrow so just and reasonable a resolution and design of the Publick, and of so near a relation to the preservation of all the Trade, Peace, my self and Hostages here, for the consideration of 2 or 3 ships particular accom∣modation, or their demurrage a moneth more or less; and if you finde them not capable of this good Counsel and reason, or not so consciencious of the other as to prefer it before their own Ends, you are to proceed with them accordingly; for, I have no such obligation to either of them, as may seem weighty enough to ballance the former.

4. Now in case any of the Factory after payment of their Leviation mony or securitie therefore, should desire to bee free to lade, or to have their Estate at Liberty; you are to tell them that by fresh Order from mee, you have command to hold the Goods, and Ships as directed, & upon the grounds aforemen∣tioned, viz. till provision for the future bee mad;e this Levia∣tion being alreayd eaten up and spent, before paid; and though you should have made any other pretence hitherunto, (though till further direction you had not Order at least to mention ought of my particular beyond the Leviation) you may ex∣cuse it lightly, and say you were merry with them, ctc. as they are often with mee.

5. If any should question the reason and ground of this proceeding now, that was never in President before, you may bid them and the Company thank themselves for a great part of it; for (besides the reasons before expressed) they have
Ordered their Factors to convey away all their Estates, and to leav mee naked here, and the General of the Trade at Ran∣dam, and every one to shift for himself; which I beeing ad∣vised of, have reason to look out as well for theirs as my own safety. Next I have heard of som Combinations against my particular, and shall desire to provide the best I may for that too; but bee sure you discover nothing of my own pretences, untill the last, and that not untill further order.

6. You will in your Warrant, and so in the Command, finde Order for rendring into your possession all goods a∣board the Ships, belonging to any of our Nation; wherein I would have you walk with great circumspection; First to discover from the Customer and Masters what and by whom laden, (I care not so much for whose accounts, though if you can get that, it will bee well, and a further advantage; for if it bee for any English I care not for whom; or if by any En∣glish laden, I care not by whom:) then to sequester it: and that done, take Caution of the Master beeing aboard, and party to whom it belongs, that it bee alway forth-coming upon further Order; which if either the Master or Merchants shall refuse, you are without further respect whatever by the Chouz and Caddie to take them into your possession, as in your Instructions, and by the Command directed, which is to be your refuge at all times. In case the Masters shall say that they cannot tell to whom the goods belong till Bills of la∣ding signed; they cannot however deny to tell you by what and by whom laden; at least the Customer if hee will, can discover it, and you are to press either according to occasion; and if need bee bring them before the Caddy to that end; and (in case they refuse) there endeavour to caus them unlade a new; wherein the Customer shall not loos his Custom, you agreeing with him to that end.

If they have not signed Bills of lading (as most likely they have not, for that is commonly the last work) discove∣ring whose goods they are, or who laded them, you are to forbid the Masters to give Bills till further Order; and if the Masters refuse or delay, to proceed against them according
to your Commands, and endeavour what you may to get them into your power, or such of them or their Estates, or the Laders and their Estates, as you best can.

7. In case of resistance or any Clamorous Hubub, as in Porters case, by the Mariners, you may require a guard of the Caddie, and promise payment for it to their content; or make use of the Castle to hold your prisoners in occasion; (for I shall little doubt to use Turkish help against those that oppose that authority of my Masters which I hold in Turkie by com∣mission: and I conjure you bee not scrupulous in that— what will com of it: However, look you proceed not rash∣ly nor unadvisedly in any thing, nor suffer your self to bee particularly provoked, and so spoil your Cause, but proceed alwaies according to the Command and style of the plain, Lawes, and formes of it (where my authority will not serv) viz. by the Caddy and power of the place, & their own officers, whatever you pay for it, which in all occasion will bee your justification and mine: and they will second your procee∣dings with Arz and Maxars from time to time to the Port; which in occasion you are to seek and to back your self and mee withall: and for this end bee sure to keep the Caddy and those about him so much yours, as not to suffer the Mer∣chants, Masters of Ships or other of the Town whoever, to have any: at least to such effect as may do you prejudice or the Cause.

8. For search and entering of houses to that end, (though that bee the substance at the Command and shadow of this dispatch, and really the substance too, in occasion) you are to proceed in that with care, respect, and moderation also having good assurance by particular marks, signs, if you can, or witness touching what you go about and pretend unto, before you force or enter any place, for books or other things.

9. Touching those four men principally appointed to be at∣tached, you shall observ a fit time for that, that is either fin∣ding them lading or to have laden since order, or to conceale their Estate, or to have conveyed them away, and thereon
take them into your possession, and if need bee (doubting their disturbance or future procedings in lading &c.) to send them away immediately by som of the Chouzes servants; which, I know will not onely startle all the rest below, and give them new occasion to a better submission, then to think to conquer by a contrast. However have som such occasion first, or at least pretend it if you want one; for ti's all one in this case, and I confess I had rather you send these men away, then meddle with the Masters (if you can avoid it) for all their principal Traders and Patrones beeing sent away, the Masters must then perforce obey or bee gon, as they are, laden or unladen, (which will trouble them more then all the o-other sort of force you can use to them.)

10. You are to observ, or at least to demand in my name, and by my order, to whom this new come Ship is consigned; and from that Party or Parties demand security in the premis∣ses; or for default proceed with him and them as in the other directed.

11. If Bogus perform not what he hath promised me (with a thousand oaths,) viz. if hee hinder not the Ships from lading, take not order, and secure you, that they depart not without your leav and my direction first had; or discover not, or en∣deavour at least by some probable waies to discover such E∣states of the Merchants as are concealed, or shall do any other trick out of Rule, or against you; without saying much to him or quarrelling the thing there, send mee word by an express immediately, and by a horsman if to bee gotten.

12. When you send any express at any time, be sure you do it privately, for the Merchants there have way to intercept Letters; And I doubt that Messe which your last promised mee the next day following may have miscarried, for hee appears not yet, it beeing four daies since the others arrival; The first Mess was twelv daies on the way, the last but eight. But I think I may thank the good Company for the formers stay, who were not willing hee should arrive before them; send therefore a servant a dayes journey out of Town with those you send hereafter, and let none know of your sending
away (not the Post-master or Cape of the Messes) till your Letters are ready, and then see them sent away presently, as be∣fore, requiring him not to take a Letter from any els but your self.

13. Though I hope there will bee no occasion for you to doubt; yet I would have you circumspect (especially if you should come to any contrast with the Masters of Ships) that the Mariners take no advantage of you by a surprize, or una∣wares do you an affront or mischief; you know what sort of beasts they are: For which respect (in occasion) you may by the Caddies Order have a guard of his Servants, Souldiers of the Castle, or Janizaries, a dozen or more as there shall bee occasion: But I have no other thing that put's mee in minde of this, but what you your self mention in yours of their Bravadoes: However give them no advantage either by your doubts or over security.

14. Lastly, (for I can at present think of nothing els ma∣terial,) if you want or think you shall want money for your occasions, you must supply your self by Bills of Ex∣change; for there is neither Credit, nor Bills to bee expect∣ed from hence, but what you have, or the Customer. In case it should come to a Vye there, and the Caddie were to bee presented, you may secure him by part of the Estate, till you can get Bills, or I provide for you. And so beeing weary and late, go to rest, resting.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your loving Kinsman and Master SACKVILE CROW.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Sir Sackvile Crow's Letter to Lorenzo Zuma in Smyrna, incourageing him to bee faithfull, June 2. 1646.
DIV2.P: YOu know at your departure from hence, I gave you and Hetherington a private Commission sealed up, and not to be opened untill occasion and farther advice; which being now confirmed unto me by the letters of the last ship which arrived the Port of Smyrna, I have written to Hetherington, and inor∣der you to proceed therein. By the Contents you will see the just grounds of that my Warrant; beeing but to let the Com∣pany see, that I have it in my power here to make my self re∣paration, in case they proceed with mee in that barbarous way they have begun. What care and Industrie I have used in their service for these 8 years, you have in part been an eye Witness to, and they all know the rest; and now (without so much as declaring the cause) to proceed with mee in the manner they do, exceeds the injustice of Turkie it self. Lo∣renzo, I have ever found you honest and faithfull to mee, in all I ever yet trusted or employed you in, and I am confident you will not fail mee in this that concernes Mee, my Wife, Children, whole Estate; wherein value your self and service to mee at what rate you will, I will recompence it, so you bee faithfull to Mee; which by the Laws of God and that Duty you owe Him you owe Mee also as a sworn Servant, especial∣ly in this of my just Defence, as against the assault of Theevs on the High-way. I will say no more, for I know you ho∣nest and true, and accordingly you shall finde Mee

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your hearty assured Friend and affectionate loving Master, SACKVILE CROW.

DIV2.HEAD: ¶ Copie of Sir Sackvile Crow's Letter to Jo Hetherington and Suma, June 8. 1646.

LETTER.P: I Have yours of the 30 of May arrived in six daies, won∣dring at the delay of mine, and your want of Order, pres∣sing my dispatche of some further help and supply of Cre∣dit.

Yours accuse the receipt of mine of the 5, 6, and 7 past; want the 17 (which I also doubt miscarried) and mine of the 27. by Bizadee Chouz could not then bee arrived you, but before this I hope may bee.

By him you will have received fresh and full Commands in assistance of your power, and by him directions (in case you wanted money) what to do, which way to repair your selvs; viz either by Bills of Exchange, or by som of the goods under your hands, in case those that promised payment there, com∣plyed not, & thereby gave you supply; for from hence I found no possibilitie of getting credit for money, and happily the Caddie would be contented (if for a reasonable sum) to take Bills of Exchange payable to some of his Friends here.

For advice in what concerned the carriage of your Busi∣ness; those Letters, as also mine of the 3 and 4 present (sent by a several expresses, as duplicates of each other) will have sufficiently instructed you, if arrived; as I hope before this they will bee.

In adjunct to which I send these confirming my former, with this addition only, viz. that you proceed to possess your selvs, as soon as you may, with what you can, and the same take into your power as pledg and securitie for the future provision of the Trade, and my indempnity from such unjust pretences as the Companie have raised against Mee. In prosecution whereof, you are to proceed by such gentle steps and paces, as may best and with least non effect your
work, and yet secure that you go about: I confess I have required of you a large summ in my last, and when I came to cast up those dammages I may sustein, the summ rather falls short of than exceeds my just doubts of their injust Endea∣vours upon what they have in their powers to prejudice mee in, and I am certified they have made themselvs Masters of in part: However I must content my self with what I may con∣veniently do, and not strein the cord too farr, least it break and requoil upon Mee, to the hazard of that hold I had of more, and what I might have made sure of, and so must leav that still to your discretion to mannage; with this Order notwithstanding, to take into your hands as much as you can of the finest Goods you can get; and where that fails, Cloathes will bee no ill merchandize, and so good security.

The Murmur here riseth every day to greater wonder, where these clouds will dissolve and terminate, which I keep obscure hitherunto, though not unsuspected; the rather, for that they say Captain Jordan is coming up, of which I hear not though deny not but hee may, (not complying and con∣forming himself as hee ought) and so who els of those there upon the same occasion: and your Rule is such at least for those 4 or 5 principally directed in my former.
As I promised you in my last, I shall begin my work here much about that time you are directed to set forward there; whereof within three or four daies you will be advised more certainly.
To morrow wee shall have a Court, and I shall there lay the foundation to the work, assuring my self of a denial before-hand, of what I am to demand; and then you may i∣magine what will follow.

My Demands will bee just, and grounded on their own Covenants, backed with Law and Equity, and so long I have seldom forsaken a good Cause; on the other side hitherto ne∣ver pursued an ill, at least contrary to my knowledg and con∣science, which by God's assistance shall bee my guide in this.

I confess I like not so well your lodging in any Merchants house; for 'twill bee impossible for you to keep your designs
from view, and your necessarie discourses from the discovery of others in an others house, where you must exspect to bee watched, and your papers sought after, and to have all possi∣ble art and intention used to circumvent you, though (I am of your minde) Mr Campion bee one of the best of them, how∣ever a Merchant still.

Next I should bee glad to hear you were removed from the water side, that is out of Marriners roade, and (if in that place you rest in you bee so) you have done the better; but whatever you do, have a care of a surprize, and next of be∣ing betrayed through any sort of confidence, or by any mens friendship whoever; and I the rather write this from some discoverie made out of these Letters which came enclosed un∣der yours, from that partie you think most sure, directed to a friend of his here, which I keep by mee against a fitter oc∣casion.

Beyond which I can say no more at present, having no∣thing of yours material and unanswered, nor further to ad∣vise, but that I rest exspecting your further advice of what you have done, that I may proceed accordingly, resting

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your very loving Friend, Sackvile Crow.

LETTER.P: YEsterdaie died the old Customer Alliaga; most of his Places here put upon Hassanchellibee, but Smyrna not yet disposed, of which I stand attending, least something might bee done in prejudice of what I have begun below: But of this you will hear more suddenly, and have fresh Commands and Orders as there shall bee occasion.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Sackvile Crow.

DIV2.HEAD: John Hetherington, and Lorenzo Suma, their Letters to Sir Sackvile Crow, advising further of their proceeding, Dated in Smyrna, 15. of June, 1646.
DIV2.P:
FInding some unwillingness in the Caddie, to cause those Goods to bee delivered into our possession, which lay sealed up under his Seal, by reason that a great part of them are pretended unto by Jews, Turks, Armenians, &c. Wee could not perform that promise wee made your Lordship, in our last, which was to give your Lordship an accompt the next day of what Goods wee had discovered, and of their value; but since understanding the Caddies minde by the late visit wee made him, have promised him dollars 1000, and to his sonnes dollars 500, and to the rest of his servants gratuities, to come either himself, or send his Son with the Neipe to mor∣row morning, and open all the Warehouses of the Nation in generall; and those goods which shall not appear to bee sold and paid for, to deliver into our possession, and the rest to keep sealed up untill wee may have answer from your Lordship concerning this particular; the Language hee un∣derstood better then our former, and hath faithfully promised, if his late indisposition would give him leav, to come and see it effected himself, or at least to send his Son, and caus all the Estate discovered, that is not pretended unto by any Sub∣jects of the Grand Signor, to be delivered into our possessi∣on; and more, if the Master of the Jonas should refuse to deliver into our possession, those Goods aboard his Ship, to assist us with some 40 or 50 Souldiers, and to enter his Ship per force; which I vow to God and your Lordship, should hee refuse to obey your Lordships Warrant, shall bee attempted; for besides the Caddies assistance, I am profered very good assi∣stance from one in port able to master him, but the man be∣ing a good subject, and a poor man withall, promising him some good reward for himself, and some consideration for the
time hee hath spent here, for his owners; I hope hee will comply, and not run the hzzard of so great a mischief, as his deniall may occasion. Wee have imployed the most cunningst Rogues in all the Country, to see if they can discover any other part of the Nations Estate either hid or lying out, but as yet they have discovered nothing, but hope when this hub∣bub is over, to finde out something; in the mean time shall not bee wanting to use our utmost indeavours, to the effe∣cting of it. If that report be true wee hear, that Hassan Che∣lobee, shall bee Customer, and Bogus return, wee may bee able to do something, though I fear not much. For though En∣glish mens Goods, yet in anothers Warehous, will finde it a difficult business to prove it sold, and delivered and paid for, and will afterwards rather trust a Turk or a Jew, then let your Lordship have it. I beseech your Lordship, with the first to inorder us how to dispose of such goods as we hope to have here, and which of them must bee sent up; the chief Com∣modities here are Cloth, Silk, Cotten yarne, Grograin yarn, &c. and they say in Master Lancelots hous is store of Tinne, (but Mr Santhill's) I hear to the value of 40 or 50000. dol∣lars; If wee can procure here dollars 100000. for your Lordships use, I hope it may help satisfie your Lordships de∣mands, 'tis but taking the more above, if your Lordship can finde it. If wee can possess our selvs of the Jonases Goods, which may amount to dollars 50000 more, being as they say half full, and all fine Goods, the Golden Lyon brought Dollars 9000 to Barnardiston; I shall search narrowly for that, and have some good assurance to finde out where the Money or Goods are; I wish my abilitie answerable to that servent desire I owe and bear to your Honors Service.

This day arrived a Saitie from Marcellis, and brings hope∣full news from England. His Majestie being blockt up in Ox∣ford, disguised himself, and with a servant or two resolved to run the hazard, and put himself into the mercy of the Scots, rather then stand to the curtesie of the Rebels at Westminster; and 5. of May, by day break, His Majestie arriv d to the Scots Army near Newarke, to the wonder and amazement of them
all, as by the Letter here inclosed your Lordship will disco∣ver. Where tis advised hee was entertained with all obedi∣dience; they presently gave the Rebbels advice of it, (as by the inclosed) who presently sent the Scotch many expressions of their thankfulness, and withall desired them to conduct him to Warwick Castle, and there to deliver him into their power: the Scotch denyed it, and craved their excuse, His Majestie be∣ing in their power; would first bee assured on what conditi∣ons His Majestie should come, and if his Majestie liked them, and was willing to goe, (otherwise their pardon,) they were His Subjects, and must obey him, and would, and pretended they sought nothing, but the good of both Kingdomes, and they did not see that His Majestie demanded any thing unrea∣sonable; upon the arrivall of this answer at London, the Scotch Commissioners and the Roundheads differed, and the Scotch Commissioners told them plainly they demanded things unreasonable for the King to grant. What issue the happy difference may breed is doubtfull, but it is ho∣p d may better His Majesties condition much, they begin at London to speak high language against the Parliament, and are doubtfull because Lord Montross is marching towards His Majestie with 12000 men. God increas his Majesties forces, and send your Lordship a happy issue of your desires and our indeavours; whilest wee presume to subscribe our selves.

SIGNED.HI: Your Honours most faithfully de∣voted and most humble Servants,

DIV2.HEAD: John Hetherington and Lorenzo Suma, their Letters to Sir Sackvile Crow, advising further of their proceedings, dated in Smyrna, 16. of June, 1646.
DIV2.P:
YEsterday wee received your Lordships of the 4 present, being the Copy of the 3. And to day wee received your Lordships of the 8. and rejoyce to hear your Lordship is in such a readiness for your just demands, and wish your Lord∣ship less trouble, and better success, then wee this day have had, and wee doubt for many dayes shall incounter here: this morning the Caddies son, with his Neipe and principall Offi∣cers came, and wee began first with the Consulls hous, but before wee began 'twas spoken in the Caddies own hous, & all over the Town, our design to seiz what we could finde; about 7 a clock his son came & entred the Consuls hous, & opened all the Warehouses, and took from thence, with Elfords and Keebles, som 400 Clothes, & 9 Bales Mohairs; we left behinde us 38 Bales of Silk, 13 Bales his servant pretended were sold by his master to Mr. Brent, to be paid by Bill of Exchange at Constantinople, and when advice came the Bills were paid, the Goods should bee delivered; in the mean time they lie in Mr. Lancelots Warehouse, with some 40 Clothes, 60 Barrels of Tynne, which Tinne belongs to Mr. Sainthill, and sealed up by the Neipe and us. Before wee had ended at this house, the whole Town was in an uprore, being fomented by Jews, and som of the young frie left behinde, and proclaimed in the Streets, that the Town would bee undone, the Trade lost and go to wrack, if this was suffered; so that before the Consulls door were so many of the scum of the Town, the Streets were packed thick of them. On the other side, a more unruly enemy threatned worse things, the Master of the Gol∣den Lyon, who had before given Barnardiston 9000 Dollars at
Cambio, and had no Goods in his possession, hearing how it would fare with them, lands 40 men at Barnardistons house, and vowed hee would have his money or goods, or swore hee would beat down the Town; so likewise the Jonas got her sails to yards, that the Caddies son and the Chiouz de∣sired to let it alone, untill another day, for fear of wors events'; so when they had made an end at Lancelots hous, would stay no longer, but promised to come another day. The Estate before mentioned wee carried away in spight of envie, and have put it up in a safe Cane: assoon as this was done, becaus the Captain would not come ashore, I got Jordan to go a bord the Golden Lion, and know the Master his intent, and to acquaint him with the danger might ensue thereon; all wee could urge was nothing, except▪ hee had satisfaction for his 9000 Dollars; at last told him, if hee knew where his Estate lay, wee would endeavour to help him to it, so hee found it out, and wee delivered it to him, and the man was very well satisfied. And now wee hope to finde little impedi∣ment, and to morrow morning the Caddies Son promiseth to come again, and wee doubt not the same day but to make an end. If your Lordship saw the little regard these people bear to the Grand Signors commands, the Caddie, or ought els but their private ends, your Lordship would (as wee hope your Lordship will) not blame us if procured but the half of what your Lordships Letter mentions. To morrow (if God bless us) wee shall send your Lordship more pun∣ctuall advice, and for the present crave leav to subscribe our selves,

CLOSER.SIGNED:
Your Honors Most faithfull, most obliged and most humble Servants,
John Hetherington.
Lorenzo Zuma.

DIV2.HEAD: John Htherington and Lorenzo Zuma's Letter to Sir Sack∣vile Crow; dated in Smyrna, 19 June, 1646.
DIV2.P:
OUrs of the 16 advised your Lordship, how with the Cad∣dies Son, his Niepe, and Chia, wee had entred the house of Mr Lancelots and taken into our possession the Goods wee found therein, not pretended unto by Strangers; and how by the insolency of Nicolas Terrick, Master of the Hope∣well (ormerly the Golden Lion) wee were interrupted that day from proceeding any farther; and how by the means of Ca∣ptain Jordan wee had pacified that young, rash, and undiscreet Man; and that we hoped the next morning to proceed with∣out interruption, but it fell not out so: for the next morn∣ing wee went to Barnardiston's house, thinking to make all sure there; and when wee had begun, in come's the Master with a crew of his own, and said, those Goods hee had re∣ceived were not sufficient to give him satisfaction, and de∣manded of us the rest; we answered, wee could not give him these Goods wee had sealed up before hee came into Pot, for what hee demanded; but assured him, if hee knew of any thing standing out, wee would endeavour the best wee could for his satisfation; upon this, as wee understood since, a young man of the house whispered the Master in his eare, and told him, if hee were not satisfied before the Goods went out of the house, all was lost, hee would never have a penny of it; upon this, away goes the Master aboard with this young man in his company, and loosed his sailes, but threatned nothing; upon this comes in the Jewes and told the Niepe and the Chia, that the Master would shoot down the Town; but for all our perswasions that hee durst not, a∣way runs the Niepe and his Company, and leaves us there a∣lone: so wee resolved to have done it our selves, but the Merchants had so worked with the Hamalls, that there
was not one to bee seen; so beeing alone, and seeing his Boat coming ashore well mann'd, and fearing a surprize, wee presently repaired to the Chiouzes, and desired him to go with us to the Caddies, to see if wee could have any better as∣sistance from him. By this time the Town was in a great up∣roar, and the people something too insolent; the Caddie to prevent the worst, presently caused the Shops to bee shut up, and immediatly sent for all the chief men of the Town, (who by presents before wee had made our Friends) and there be∣fore them all, and a great company of the Townesmen, cau∣sed the Commands to bee read, and told them how much they were bound to see the Grand Signors Commands put in execution, and what dishonor it would bee for one Ship to command the Town: so after they had disputed the Busi∣ness, the Caddie sends an Officer aboard (accompanyed with the Druggerman to the Nation) to know whether hee would hinder the prosecution of the Grand Signors Command or no, and to know his answer; hee presently denyed hee ever intended to shoot at the Town, onely desired his own; so presently after the people were a little appeased, wee went to work again, and so this day have finished all: it beeing done in such confusion, wee cannot give your Lordship that exact accompt you may expect, within a day or two; for then wee will send your Lordship the particulars, with the values, in mean time wee stand upon our guard, having some 20 or 30 of the Souldiers of the Castle to keep watch every night; for, (my Lord!) here is no small hubbub in the Town, and threatning both of us and the Estate, but wee will secure both as well as wee can. Wee have sent your Lordship a rough draught of what wee have, and what wee have left sealed up, and finde it fall short farre of what your Lordship expected: the sooner your Lordship disposes of it, the better; for assure your self, there is daily some designe or other hatching; wee should bee very sorry after all this to have it miscarry, therefore pray (my Lord!) dispose of it (to prevent the worst) as soon as you may. Your Lordship was pleased to inorder us to change ou Lodging, beeing too near
the Water-side, and in a Merchants hous; which, as soon as wee can get a secure house, wee will; but the farther from the Water-side, the more dangerous, if the people of the Coun∣try should intend us any ill.

The French and many others, pretend Debts of many of those people that are gone up, and would know who shall pay them, and pretend to bee paid out of their Estates; but wee have put them off, telling them, wee believe your Lordship will hardly let your Estate go to pay their Debts; neverthe∣less, shall advise your Lordship of it: so have secured none, onely to one Huzoone Amet Aga, one of the chief men in the Town here, Mr Lancelott having given him a Bill of Ex∣change for 475 Dollars, and the Bill returned unpaid, wee were forced to deliver into the Hangees hands for his secu∣rity 10. Cloathes.

Wee have given the Ships liberty to lade, by reason of their continual grumbling, but fear our design on the Jonas will not take; for the Caddie seeing the stubborness of Terrick, will not assist us as hee promised. Wee have not ought to inlarge at present, but to subscribe our selvs,

DIV2.HEAD: Another Letter of John Hetherington and Lorenzo Zuma to Sir Sackvile Crow. Dated 26th June, 1646. in Smyr∣na.
DIV2.P:
SInce our last of the 19th of June, there has not much hap∣pened here worth giving your Lordship trouble in these busie times, nor any of your Lordships to answer; wee here∣with send your Lordship enclosed the Copy of what Goods wee have taken from the Merchants houses, authenticated by the Caddie, the Original wee keep here by us; by it your Lord-will soon see what will bee fit for Constantinople Market, and wee hope your Lordship will the sooner dispose of it: The Lead, Tynne, and Wyer will never vent so well here as at Constantinople, but how 'twill bee conveyed thither, wee can∣not advise your Lordship; by Land 'twill bee too great a charge for so course a Commodity, and by Sea it will run too great a hazard, except we could get some English or French Ship to carry it up, but a farr greater if it lie here, if that Rogue Moyer come in, before it and the rest of the Estate bee conveyed away from hence; for the greatest part of the Lead concerns his proper Accompt, and findng two such Compa∣nions in Port, as the Master of the Triangle, and Hopewell, by his insolency (for your Lordship well knows how little hee values your Lordships authority) may so startle these discon∣tented and affrighted People here of the Town, that wee shall have a hard task to oppose him or them; but if your Lord∣ship please to clear the Estate from hence first, wee shall bee the better able to deal with them, and his Companions, when wee are rid of it; as for the Cloth, little or none of it will off here, the Town beeing so full at present, that may come up by Carravan; and if your Lordship think fit, the Grograin yarn, Mohaire, Wax, &c. Goods that are fit for Christendom, may bee shipt away from hence and consigned
to whom your Lordship shall appoint, it's but changing the Covers, and new marking of them. Wee beseech your Lord∣ship to bee as speedy in the disposure of this Estate, as with your Lordships best advantage may bee convenient: For my Lord, the truth is, wee do a little doubt the security of it, as it lies here, and were your Lordship an eie-witness to those insolencies wee daily see here against the Caddie, and Grand Signors power, your Lordship would endeavour a speedy removal of it, as wee may seem to bee importunate to your Lordship. For,
The Master and Merchants dare not trust themselvs ashore, onely Jordan, and three or-four of the Factors that are good subjects to his Majesty.

Wee have been forced to pay privately some Debts to the Grandees of the Town to stop their mouthes; as that to Ha∣zume Mamet Aga, for the Bill of Exchange hee had of Mr Lancelotts, and was forced to give them a 11 Clothes for his Debt; so likewise to a Greek of the place, one that was ser∣vant to Monsieur Jean de Puii, who pretends Barnardiston is his Debtor 410 Dollars, hee beeing in Prison; Monsieur Jean de Puii desires us to lend the man two Clothes, and hee has obliged himself to us here, that if your Lordship allow not of it, hee will bee responsible for it.

Wee have been forced to deposite some of the Clothes for Dollars 1000, at 24 per Cent. interest, not finding any one that will trust us for Constantinople; and I hope this will serve our turnes whil'st wee are here: however, if your Lordship can furnish us with any Credit in occasion, it will bee the better.

The last night arrive Newes here, that your Lordship has imprisoned the whole Nation at Constantinople, but from which of the Nations hands wee cannot discover, and how your Lordship makes large Demands upon them, and has declared Master Wylde uncapable of the charg of Consul, having taken the Covenant, which makes all these that are left here almost at their wits ends. Wee wish your Honour that successfull Issue, wee
are confident your just Demands merit in this, and all o∣ther your Designes, whil'st wee presume to subscribe our selves,

SIGNED.HI: Your Honours Most faithfully devoted and most humble Servants,

DIV2.HEAD: Another Letter of John Hetherington and Lorenzo Zuma to Sir Sackvile Crow, Dated the 26 of June, 1646, in Smyrna.
DIV2.P:
I Just now received your Lordships of the 22 present, by Sabanbasha, and with a heart as full of sorrow (though I vow to God no way startled, nor any way afraid for your Lordships ill success) as any living; but do much lament your Lordships hard fortune, to bee betrayed by a Companie of Rogues: Whatever becomes of us here, (let but your Lordship have your ends of those Devills above) 'tis no matter; that life, your Goodness hath been pleased to preserve hitherto, cannot bee better spent than in your Service, and except in his Majesties, I can∣not think it better bestowed. I beseech your Lordship take no care for us, nor to much trouble your more serious thoughts for such doubts some may put into your minde of our safeties. My Lord, wee shall obey
your Honors Commands in all things, and should I finde but an unwillingness in my right hand, or a disobedi∣ence in it, (by the faith I owe to God) I would cut it off. So good my Lord bee confident, wee are

SIGNED.HI: Your Honours Most constant, most faithfull, and most humble Servants,

P.HI: The Money mentioned in the Letter (accompanying this) to have taken upon Cloth, will not bee paid us, except the Owner of the Cloth will bee bound for it.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Joh. Hetherington.

DIV2.HEAD: Another Letter of Sir Sackvile Crow in Constantinople, to John Hetherington and Lorenzo Zuma. Dated the 1 of July 1646.
DIV2.P:
YOu will have wondered much I am sure, why in all this time you have not heard from mee, amidst so much nois and ado; but I have been constant to my old Rule, I love not to trouble my self in hurlies of this nature, which must come to the rule of Reason at last. I have stood still to see these mad people spend 30000 Dollars at least, onely for a Command to release those Goods you have sequestred, and
to bring you and Lorenzo up to the Port; and this they have not in their hands neither, it stayes for the payment of Dol∣lars 5000 more; and then I am promised another quite con∣trary; which if the other should succeed to their desires, you may expect by an express, to bee there assoon as theirs, if not before; In the mean time I send you here the Copy of their Arze to the Vizier; to the end the Caddie there may bee ad∣vised of their falshood, and of their attempts against him here, which I will never forsake him in; and so you may assure him what ever it cost mee; hee having done nothing for ought I see or here, but what is justified to him by Capitulati∣ons, several Commands, the Viziers own Servant, and Chiouzes sent expresly to see it executed; on the other side, you may upon this make Mazars of the late insolency of the Nations taking away the Captain of a Ship out of the Consuls house every day (not having their will) menacing the Town with shot and Armes, upon the least occasion; threatning the Cad∣die and his Officers in such sort, as that they dare not execute their Offices, and the Grand Signors Commands; with such other circumstances as you shall hold sit, and bee btter privy unto, and able to make good; as perswading the people of the place to mutiny and disorders, &c. insomuch that you were forced to require a guard, &c. for which, if need bee, you are to desire the Caddie in occasion to afford you Arze to the Port, and of your behaviour in that charge committed to you: I hope and doubt not but you have taken good wit∣ness of what Goods and Estates you have taken out of their Houses, &c. for amongst the rest of their Avaniaes and villa∣nies they dayly coine, they say you have taken from them all their Estates; which they pretend to bee sometimes to the value of 600000 Dollars; sometimes 300000; and sometimes 200000. I heartily wish it were but as much as the least of these summes, if not the most; whatever it bee, more then what you last sent mee in yours of the 19 of June (if ought more, which I believ not) I pray send mee word, and by a Horseman alwaies express; for yours of the 16 fell into the Rebells hands, and your last gave mee no Copy of it. What
noise soever you encounter, I charge you budg not out of your place, or posture; for the storm is over, and God bee thanked I have broken their waves. And I doubt not but you will see a calme game played for the after one; for which I have fair blots, if any of them hit; hitherunto it hath not cost mee an Asper, for till the Officers bellies were prettily well filled at my neighbours, I knew they would bee costly guests on such occasions; now having been feasted with them a day, two, or three, I shall provide a banquet for them too, but at their cost (take my word) that are the occasion of my trouble. By the next express I pray send mee back those Ac∣counts of Consulage I gave you John Hetherington under Brents and Lancelotts hands, and advise mee whether you have learnt any more of those particulars Read told you of; and whe∣ther you have Lancelotts papers and Accompts under your power; and bee sure whatever you have, hold, and make them safe. 'Tis a wonder to mee I confess I hear not oftner from you, in your Instructions requiring it so strictly, and in every Letter putting you in mind of it; let mee hear here∣after though it bee nothing but Duplicates, every three dayes at the farthest; and bee sure (if you send about any important business) that you send a Horseman; if with duplicates, by Footmen: you must send some one or other with them, a day or a half daies journey, or els you may give them for lost; for these people lay all their wayes they can for interception. I have not more to trouble you with at present, but to desire you not to bee troubled with these troubles and encounters, that might justly bee exspected in a business of this nature, though not driven to this height; but the Sun it self hath its time of declining, and so Mr. Lancelott and his Gompany. God bee with you, and direct you, whilst I rest,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your loving Friend, and Sackvile Crow.

POSTSCRIPT.HEAD: POSTSCRIPT.
POSTSCRIPT.P: THe Visier you see by the Arze inclosed, would have had the caus heard before the Caddielescars at the Turkish Law, but I sent him word they were strangers to mee, and I had nothing to do with them: I knew no law here but my Capitulations; and when that was not known for law betwixt my Master and the Grand Signor, I desired I might have leav to tell him so. Dominico, Dominico hath been the grand Traitor to mee, and played the Devill, the Arch-devill with mee in this busi∣ness, debashed, and frighted Georgi and the rest from mee, and stoll away my Capitulations and Records, and is now Secretary to the Apprentices of Gallata; where hee and the rest keep close, and are ashamed to shew their faces; for the very boyes of the Streets hout and scorn them for their fals∣hood. They were few dayes since at the French Ambassadors for audience for the Company; who told them, that hee knew the King of England, and had known them as Servants to his Majesties Ambassador; but hee had not heard Master Company before; when hee had had audience with the Grand Signor, and knew what Country man hee was, and whether his Masters friend or no, hee would give them an answer, or much to this purpose: which you may tell for news of Gal∣lata, from whence you will hear more ere long. S.C.
Not being willing to stay the Copying and registring the inclosed, I send you the Originall as it came to mee from the Viziers.

CLOSER.SIGNED: S. Crow.

DIV1.TRAILER: Thus farr concerning the intercourse held between Sir Sackvile Crow in Constantinople, and his Agents John Hetherington, and Lorenzo Züma, with others in Smyrna.

DIV1.HEAD: Now followeth the PETITION of the Nation in Constantinople to Sir Sackvile Crow, and his Reply thereunto; together with the Factors Letters in Constantinople and Smyrna, to the Company in London.

DIV2.HEAD: The Petition of the Nation at Constantinople, to Sackvile Crow, dated 20 June, 1646. To the Right Honorable Sir Sackvile Crow Baronet Am∣bassadour for his Majestie of Great Britain, with the Grand Signor.
DIV2.P:
WHereas at a Court held the 18 of this month of June, 1646. by your Lordship and both Factories of Constantinople and Smyrna, after sundry debates, your Lord∣ship declared unto the Nation that by se∣verall wayes you were advised, the Le∣vant Company in England had prevailed with the Parliament, and sequestred your Lordships Estate in Lands, as also were endeavoring to send out to surprize your person, without signifying the cause wherefore; and thereupon your Lord ship demanded of us satisfaction for your said Estate, and security for your Hono∣rable
person, leaving it in generall terms to our farther con∣fiderations, how and which way your Lordship might bee so secured; in the interim confining us to your hous, whence wee should not depart, nor the Ships in Port bee dispeeded, untill your Lordships demands were complyed with con∣cerning the premisses, and the day following to sundry of us, who in behalf of the whole Nation repaired to your Lord∣ship to know the particulars of your demands, made these ensuing Propositions: viz.
